{{HVAC}}
[[Category:Heaters]] [[Category:Home appliances]]

{{more citations needed|date=February 2008}} :''For the researcher into architecture and blues music, see [[Paul Oliver]].'' '''Paul Ambrose Oliver''' (July 18, 1831 – May 17, 1912) was an [[United States|American]] [[explosive]]s inventor, [[American Civil War]] [[Union Army]] [[Captain (United States O-3)|captain]] and staff officer who was appointed to the [[Brevet (military)|brevet]] grade of [[Brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]] and [[Medal of Honor]] recipient.Eicher, John H., and [[David J. Eicher]], ''Civil War High Commands.'' Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2001. {{ISBN|0-8047-3641-3}}. p. 409 He was born on the "Louisiana", his father's merchant ship, during one of its voyages in the [[English Channel]]. Before the Civil War, he worked as a shipping merchant. In January 1862, Oliver joined the [[12th New York Volunteer Infantry]] as a [[second lieutenant]]. During the war, he served as an aide to no fewer than four generals, including [[Daniel Butterfield]], [[George Meade]], [[Joseph Hooker]] and [[Gouverneur K. Warren]]. While he accepted a promotion to captain in April 1864, he declined further promotions. On March 8, 1865, [[President of the United States|President]] [[Abraham Lincoln]] nominated Oliver for appointment as a brevet brigadier general to rank from March 8, 1865 and the U.S. Senate confirmed the appointment on March 10, 1865.Eicher, 2001, p. 754 Oliver resigned his commission on May 6, 1865. Oliver was an inventor and powder manufacturer after the Civil War. Paul Ambrose Oliver died May 17, 1912 at Laurel Run, Pennsylvania. He was buried at [[Green-Wood Cemetery]], [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. ==Medal of Honor citation== Rank and organization: Captain, Company D, 12th New York Infantry. Place and date: Resaca, Ga., 15 May 1864. Entered service at: New York, N.Y. Born: 18 July 1831, at sea in the English Channel. Date of issue: 12 October 1892.
While acting as aide assisted in preventing a disaster caused by Union troops firing into each other.
==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * Eicher, John H., and [[David J. Eicher]], ''Civil War High Commands.'' Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2001. {{ISBN|0-8047-3641-3}}. == External links == * [http://all-biographies.com/soldiers/paul_a_oliver.htm Biography] * [https://archive.org/stream/cu31924020334771#page/n57/mode/2up 1893 Biographical Sketch] * {{Find a Grave|3309}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Oliver, Paul Ambrose}} [[Category:1830 births]] [[Category:1912 deaths]] [[Category:United States Army Medal of Honor recipients]] [[Category:Union Army officers]] [[Category:American Civil War recipients of the Medal of Honor]] {{US-engineer-stub}} {{explosive-stub}}

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category 21st-century movements to [[:Category:21st-century social movements]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 August 5]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox Union |name= Planka.nu |country= [[Sweden]] |affiliation= |members= |full_name= |native_name= Planka.nu |image= [[Image:Hoppagubben.gif|150px]] |founded= 2001 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= |people= |website= [http://planka.nu planka.nu] |footnotes= }}
'''Planka.nu''' is a network of organizations in [[Sweden]] and [[Norway]] promoting [[tax]]-financed [[zero-fare public transport]] with chapters in [[Stockholm]], [[Gothenburg]], [[Skåne]], [[Östergötland]] and [[Oslo]].<ref name="planka-om">{{cite web | url = http://planka.nu/om-plankanu | title = Om Planka.nu | work = Planka.nu | accessdate = 2010-01-25 | quote = }}</ref> Planka.nu was founded in 2001 by the [[Swedish Anarcho-syndicalist Youth Federation]] in response to the increasingly expensive ticket prices in the [[Public transport in Stockholm|public transport system in Stockholm]]. The campaign has received much attention because of the controversial methods used to promote free [[public transport]]: Planka.nu encourage people to [[Fare dodging|fare-dodge]] in the public transport,<ref name="fpt">{{cite web | url = http://www.freepublictransports.com/Planka.nu | title = Planka.nu | work = Free Public Transport | accessdate = 2010-01-25 | quote = }}</ref> <ref name="planka-darfor">{{cite web | url = http://planka.nu/vad-tycker-vi/darfor-vagrar-vi-betala | title = Avgiftsstrejk | work = Planka.nu | accessdate = 2010-01-25 | quote = }}</ref> aiding its members in paying [[penalty fare]]s through the insurance fund ''p-kassan''.<ref name="planka-pkassan">{{cite web | url = http://planka.nu/plankning/stockholm/pkassan | title = P-kassan är en bötesfond för plankare i Stockholms kollektivtrafik | work = Planka.nu | accessdate = 2010-01-24 | quote = P-kassan är en solidaritetskassa. Som medlem hjälper du andra plankare att få sina böter betalda. När du själv åker fast är det andra plankare som betalar din tilläggsavgift. }}</ref>
== History == In 2001, the Stockholm chapter of the Swedish Anarcho-syndicalist Youth Federation ({{lang-sv|SUF, Syndikalistiska Ungdomsförbundet}}) launched the campaign Planka.nu (literally, ''fare-dodge.now'') as a reaction to a rise in ticket prices by the [[Stockholm County Council]].<ref name="planka-om"/> The domain name [[.nu]], which belongs to the {{convert|260|km²|adj=on}} island of [[Niue]] but is sold primarily to foreigners, was chosen because it means "now" in [[Swedish language|Swedish]]. The standard [[top level domain]] for Sweden is [[.se]].
With growing membership and interest, the campaign was detached from the SUF to form an independent organization. Local organizations have since started up in [[Gothenburg]] in 2003, [[Östergötland]] in 2005 and [[Skåne]] in 2009.<ref name=planka-om /> A sister organization, ''pumm.it'' has been created in [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]].<ref name="pummit">{{cite web |url = http://planka.nu/pummit |title = Pummit - moi mukulat |work = Planka.nu |accessdate = 2010-01-26 |quote = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100813125840/http://planka.nu/pummit |archivedate = 2010-08-13 |df = }}</ref> In November 2008, Planka.nu released [http://freepublictransports.com Freepublictransports.com], a global forum for the free public transport movement.
Ticket fares in Stockholm have increased dramatically over time. By one measure—single ticket price for a {{convert|10|km|adj=on}} journey—Stockholm has the most expensive-to-use public transport in the world, as of March 2009.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.economist.com/displayStory.cfm?story_id=14396066 |title=A fare price?| publisher=[[The Economist]]| date=September 24, 2009| accessdate=2009-09-24| quote=In Stockholm it costs $4.88 for a single journey of 10km on public transport, the highest cost in a study of 73 cities by [[UBS AG|UBS]], a Swiss bank.}}</ref>
== Activism == [[File:COP15Plankanu.jpg|thumb|250px|Planka.nu demonstrating at the [[COP15]].]] In the tradition of the [[Italians|Italian]] [[autonomist]]s,<ref name="indymedia">{{cite web| url =http://sweden.indymedia.org/newswire/display_any/20075| title =Planka.nu och autoreduktion| first =| last =SAM| date =2002-04-20| month =| year =| work =IMC Sverige| publisher =[[Indymedia]]| accessdate =2010-01-25| quote =| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://archive.is/20130415012936/http://sweden.indymedia.org/newswire/display_any/20075| archivedate =2013-04-15| df =}}</ref> Planka.nu advocate [[self-reduction]], where the price of the [[Service (economics)|service]] is determined by the [[consumer]].<ref name="planka-sjalvreduktion">{{cite web | url = http://planka.nu/vad-tycker-vi/sjalvreduktion | title = Självreduktion | work = Planka.nu | accessdate = 2010-01-25 | quote = }}</ref> Whereas in other cases this is done in agreement with (at least some) [[employee]]s of the [[service provider]], in the case of Planka.nu fare-dodgers are encouraged to evade fares without seeking permission.
Since its conception Planka.nu has broadened its methods and now functions as a [[think tank]] with public transport, [[urban planning]] and [[Global warming|climate change]] as its main areas of focus,<ref name=fpt /><ref name="fpt-annual09">{{cite web | url = http://www.freepublictransports.com/blog/2010/01/annual-report-from-planka-nu-stockholm-sweden/ | title = Annual report from Planka.nu (Stockholm, Sweden) | work = Free Public Transport | accessdate = 2010-02-01 | quote = }}</ref> as well as an insurance fund. The network also uses standard [[leftist]] methods, such as [[Demonstration (people)|rallies]],<ref name="fpt-annual08">{{cite web | url = http://www.freepublictransports.com/blog/2009/05/annual-report-for-2008-from-plankanu-stockholm-sweden/ | title = Annual report for 2008 from Planka.nu (Stockholm, Sweden) | work = Free Public Transport | accessdate = 2010-02-01 | quote = }}</ref> [[adbusting]],<ref name=fpt-annual09 /> and [[pamphlet]]s.<ref name="planka-information">{{cite web |url = http://planka.nu/engagera-dig/informationsmaterial |title = Informationsmaterial |work = Planka.nu |accessdate = 2010-02-01 |quote = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100302014519/http://www.planka.nu/engagera-dig/informationsmaterial |archivedate = 2010-03-02 |df = }}</ref> Together with refugee rights organization [http://ingenillegal.org/introduction Ingen människa är illegal], the Swedish chapter of [[No one is illegal]], Planka.nu provides tickets for [[immigrant]]s living in Sweden without [[right to asylum|asylum]],<ref name=planka-ekonomi /> since a [[Illegal immigration|paperless immigrant]] might otherwise be reported to the police and deported if caught riding without a ticket.
=== P-kassan === Failing to purchase a ticket or traveling using an incorrect pass is subject to a [[penalty fare]] of 1200 [[Swedish krona|SEK]] in the public transport systems of Stockholm,<ref>{{cite web|title=Om du fuskåker|publisher=AB Storstockholms Lokaltrafik|url=http://sl.se/Resenar/Resegaranti-resevillkor/Resa-utan-eller-med-fel-biljett/|accessdate=2010-10-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100824205024/https://sl.se/Resenar/Resegaranti-resevillkor/Resa-utan-eller-med-fel-biljett/|archivedate=2010-08-24|df=}}</ref> Gothenburg<ref>{{cite web|title=Biljettkontroll|publisher=Västtrafik|url=http://www.vasttrafik.se/sv/Att-resa/Biljettkontroll/|accessdate=2010-01-26}}</ref> and Östergötland.<ref>{{cite web|title=Du har väl giltig biljett?|publisher=ÖstgötaTrafiken|url=http://www.ostgotatrafiken.se/templates/WidePage____9645.aspx|accessdate=2010-01-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080121202301/http://www.ostgotatrafiken.se/templates/WidePage____9645.aspx|archivedate=2008-01-21|df=}}</ref> In return for a membership fee (paid monthly or biannually) members are refunded by Planka.nu if fined, through the solidarity fund ''P-kassan''.<ref name=planka-pkassan /> Net income from p-kassan is used in the aforementioned partnership with ''No one is illegal'' and to finance the production of flyers, stickers, folders, web pages and other information material. All members of Planka.nu work [[pro-bono]].<ref name="planka-ekonomi">{{cite web | url = http://planka.nu/om-plankanu/ekonomi | title = Ekonomi | work = Planka.nu | accessdate = 2010-10-17 | quote = }}</ref><ref name="tv4-cliffordson">{{Citation |last = Cliffordson |first = Ida |date = 2010-01-20 |title = Planka.nu anmäls till skatteverket |edition = |series = TV4Nyheterna Göteborg |place = |publication-place = |publisher = [[TV4 (Sweden)|TV4]] |url = http://www.tv4play.se/nyheter/lokala_nyheter/goteborg?videoId=1.1452297 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120302091524/http://www.tv4play.se/nyheter/lokala_nyheter/goteborg?videoId=1.1452297 |archivedate = 2012-03-02 |df = }}</ref>
In December 2009, [[Västtrafik]] accused the Gothenburg chapter of operating an unauthorized insurance.<ref name=tv4-cliffordson /><ref name="gp-nystrom">{{cite web | url = http://www.gp.se/nyheter/goteborg/1.264921-vasttrafik-vill-stoppa-planka-nu | title = Västtrafik vill stoppa planka.nu | first = Ulf | last = Nyström | date = 2009-12-04 | month = | year = | work = GP.se | publisher = | accessdate = 2010-01-24 | quote = Organisationen planka.nu bedriver försäkringsverksamhet, säger Johnny Bröndt (M), vice ordförande i Västtrafiks styrelse. […] Så vet jag vet har planka.nu varken tillstånd till försäkringsverksamhet eller deklarerar intäkter, utgifter och eventuellt överskott. Det är inte längre någon ideell organisation.}}</ref>
== Criticism == {{see also|Free public transport#Criticism}} Planka.nu and its organizers have seen substantial criticism, primarily by politicians and transportation companies in each city. The network has been reported to the police for [[incitement]] by [[Storstockholms Lokaltrafik]] (SL),<ref name="dn-hermele">{{cite web | url = http://www.dn.se/sthlm/sl-polisanmaler-plankanu-1.299698 | title = SL polisanmäler Planka.nu | first = Bernt | last = Hermele | date = 2004-08-21 | month = | year = | work = DN.se | publisher = | accessdate = 2010-01-25 | quote = }}</ref> Västtrafik and ÖstgötaTrafiken, who believe that Planka.nu engages in illegal activities. As of today, no charges have been made. Planka.nu themselves believe that their activities do not conflict with existing legislation.<ref name="planka-lagligt">{{cite web | url = http://planka.nu/kto/lagligt | title = Lagligt? | work = Planka.nu | accessdate = 2010-01-26 | quote = }}</ref>
Many critics believe that [[fare evasion]] leads to reduced funds and higher costs for public transport, which must be offset by higher prices for those who do pay their fares.<ref name=gp-nystrom /><ref name="dn-palmgren">{{citation | last = Palmgren | first = Nils | title = Skärpt strid om fuskåkning | date = 2004-05-27 | month = | year = | work = [[Dagens Nyheter]] | publisher = | quote = 200 miljoner kronor om året kostar fuskåkandet SL varje år. Enligt företaget gör det månadskortet 50 kronor dyrare än vad det skulle behöva vara.}}</ref>
In 2004, the [[Stockholm University#Student unions|Stockholm University Student Union]] received media attention after first permitting a meeting of the network on its premises and later barring Planka.nu when criticism was voiced.<ref name="dn-kihlstrom">{{cite web | url = http://www.dn.se/sthlm/plankanu-vallar-spricka-i-studentkar-1.319281 | title = Planka.nu vållar spricka i studentkår | first = Staffan | last = Kihlström | date = 2004-10-23 | month = | year = | work = DN.se | publisher = | accessdate = 2010-01-25 | quote = }}</ref>
== Publications == Planka.nu has released four larger [[White paper|policy papers]]: ''Highway to Hell?'' criticizing the plans for the express [[beltway]] [[Förbifart Stockholm]] around [[Stockholm]],<ref name="highwaypdf">{{Citation |title = Highway to Hell? |url = http://planka.nu/reports/plankanu_highway_to_hell.pdf |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100813125420/http://planka.nu/reports/plankanu_highway_to_hell.pdf |archivedate = 2010-08-13 |format = |accessdate = 2010-01-25 |date = November 2007 |publisher = Planka.nu |language = Swedish |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref> ''Travel Doesn't Have to Cost the Earth'' proposing a set of measures to make the transport sector in Stockholm more [[Economics of global warming#Mitigation|climate-friendly]],<ref name="travelpdf">{{Citation |title = Travel Doesn't Have to Cost the Earth |url = http://planka.nu/reports/planka_stockholm_report.pdf |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091229175958/http://planka.nu/reports/planka_stockholm_report.pdf |archivedate = 2009-12-29 |format = |accessdate = 2010-01-25 |date = 2009-09-22 |origyear = 2008 |publisher = Planka.nu |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref> ''Till varje pris?'' (''At any cost?'') a report about the costs of ticketing in the public transport system in Stockholm,<ref name="tillvarjepdf">{{Citation |title = Till varje pris? |url = http://planka.nu/reports/plankanu_till_varje_pris.pdf |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100812215850/http://planka.nu/reports/plankanu_till_varje_pris.pdf |archivedate = 2010-08-12 |format = |accessdate = 2010-01-25 |date = March 2009 |publisher = Planka.nu |language = Swedish |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref> and ''Trafikmaktsordningen'' (''The Trafic Power Structure'') regarding the [[hierarchy|hierarchies]] of [[transportation]] and how it relates to [[social mobility]] and [[social class|class]].<ref name="trafikmaktpdf">{{Citation |title = Trafikmaktsordningen |url = http://planka.nu/reports/plankanu_trafikmaktsordningen.pdf |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091222033223/http://planka.nu/reports/plankanu_trafikmaktsordningen.pdf |archivedate = 2009-12-22 |format = |accessdate = 2010-01-25 |date = December 2009 |publisher = Planka.nu |language = Swedish |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref>
== See also == *[[Ticket barrier]] *[[Stockholm Metro]] *[[Gothenburg tram]]

revision.comment: /* See also */ removed [[Punnett square]]. Clearly irrelevant
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=March 2013}} In [[cryptography]], the '''Polybius square''', also known as the '''Polybius checkerboard''', is a device invented by the Ancient Greeks Cleoxenus and Democleitus, and perfected by the [[Ancient Greek]] [[historian]] and scholar [[Polybius]],<ref>[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Polybius/10*.html#45.6 Hist. X.45.6 ff.]</ref> for [[transposition cipher#Fractionation|fractionating]] [[plaintext]] characters so that they can be represented by a smaller set of symbols.
==Basic form== The original square used the [[Greek alphabet]], but it can be used with any other alphabet. In fact, it has also been used with Japanese [[hiragana]] (see [[cryptography in Japan]]). With the modern [[English alphabet]], this is the typical form:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! ! 1 !! 2 !! 3 !! 4 !! 5 |- ! 1 | [[A]] || [[B]] || [[C]] || [[D]] || [[E]] |- ! 2 | [[F]] || [[G]] || [[H]] || [[I]]/[[J]] ||[[K]] |- ! 3 | [[L]] || [[M]] || [[N]] || [[O]] || [[P]] |- ! 4 | [[Q]] || [[R]] || [[S]] || [[T]] || [[U]] |- ! 5 | [[V]] || [[W]] || [[X]] || [[Y]] || [[Z]] |}
Each letter is then represented by its coordinates in the grid. For example, "BAT" becomes "12 11 44". Because 26 characters do not quite fit in a square, it is rounded down to the next lowest square number by combining two letters (usually C and K or sometimes I and J). (Polybius had no such problem because the Greek alphabet has 24 letters.) Alternatively, the ten digits could be added, and 36 characters would be put into a 6 × 6 grid.
Such a larger grid might also be used for the [[Cyrillic alphabet]] (the most common variant has 33 letters, but some have fewer and some have up to 37).
==Telegraphy and steganography == Polybius did not originally conceive of his device as a cipher so much as an aid to [[telegraphy]]; he suggested the symbols could be signalled by holding up pairs of sets of [[torch]]es. It has also been used, in the form of the "[[knock code]]" to signal messages between cells in [[prison]]s by tapping the numbers on pipes or walls. It is said to have been used by [[Nihilist movement|nihilist]] prisoners of the [[Russia]]n [[Czar]]s and also by [[US]] [[prisoners of war]] during the [[Vietnam War]].
[[Arthur Koestler]] describes the code being used by political prisoners of [[Stalin]] in the 1930s in his anti-totalitarian novel ''[[Darkness at Noon]]''. (Koestler had been a prisoner-of-war during the [[Spanish Civil War]].) Indeed, it can be signalled in many simple ways (flashing lamps, blasts of sound, [[jungle drums|drums]], [[smoke signal]]s) and is much easier to learn than more sophisticated codes like the [[Morse code]]. However, it is also somewhat less efficient than more complex codes.
The simple representation also lends itself to [[steganography]]. The figures from one to five can be indicated by [[knot]]s in a string, stitches on a quilt, contiguous letters before a wider space or many other ways.
==Cryptography== The Polybius cipher can be used with a [[Keyword cipher|keyword]] like the [[Playfair cipher]]. By itself the Polybius square is not terribly secure, even if used with a [[substitution cipher|mixed alphabet]]. The pairs of digits, taken together, just form a simple substitution in which the symbols happen to be pairs of digits. In this sense it is just another encoding which can be cracked with simple frequency analysis. However a Polybius square offers the possibility of [[transposition cipher#Fractionation|fractionation]], leading toward [[Claude E. Shannon]]'s [[confusion and diffusion]]. As such, it is a useful component in several [[cipher]]s such as the [[ADFGVX cipher]], the [[Nihilist cipher]], and the [[bifid cipher]].
== See also == * [[Fryctoria]] * [[Straddling checkerboard]] * [[Tap code]] * [[Topics in cryptography]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Cryptography navbox | classical}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Polybius Square}} [[Category:Classical ciphers]] [[Category:History of telecommunications]] [[Category:Steganography]] [[Category:Ancient Arcadia]]

{{Other uses2|Pot luck}} {{refimprove|date=August 2012}}
[[Image:Potluck06.jpg|thumb|300px|An assortment of different dishes at a church potluck]] A '''potluck''' is a communal gathering where each guest or group contributes a different, often homemade [[dish of food]] to be shared.
Other names for a "potluck" include: potluck dinner, spread, Jacob's join,<ref>Partridge, Eric and Paul Beale. ''A Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English, 8th ed.'' (1984).</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Bachelor |first=Lisa |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |title=Surviving on a student budget |date=October 4, 2002 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/money/2002/oct/04/studentfinance.creditanddebt2}}</ref> Jacob's supper, faith supper, covered-dish-supper, dish party, bring-and-share, shared lunch, pitch-in, bring-a-plate, dish-to-pass, fuddle, fellowship meal, and carry-in.
== Etymology == While there exists some disagreement as to its origin, two principal theories exist: the combination of the English "pot" and "luck" or the [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|North American indigenous]] [[communal meal]] ''[[potlatch]]''.
The word ''pot-luck'' appears in the [[16th century England|16th century English]] work of [[Thomas Nashe]], and used to mean "food provided for an unexpected or uninvited guest, the luck of the pot." {{Cite quote|date=September 2013}} The modern execution of a "communal meal, where guests bring their own food," most likely originated in the 1930s during the Depression <ref>Flora, Martin. [http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1933/01/27/page/14/article/potluck-meal-innovation-due-to-depression "Potluck Meal Innovation Due to Depression: Guests Chip in With Part of Dinner"], ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', Chicago, 27 January 1933. Retrieved on 5 March 2017.</ref>.
The alternative origin of the word is associated with a tradition common to the [[Tlingit]] and other indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest, called a potlatch, and is considered by opponents of this theory to be an [[eggcorn]] or [[malapropism]].
== Description == Potluck dinners are events where the attendees bring a dish to a meal. Potluck dinners are often organized by religious or [[community]] groups, since they simplify the meal planning and distribute the costs among the participants. Smaller, more informal get-togethers with distributed food preparation may also be called potlucks. The only traditional rule is that each dish be large enough to be shared among a good portion (but not necessarily all) of the anticipated guests. In some cases each participant agrees ahead of time to bring a single course, and the result is a multi-course meal. Guests may bring in any form of food, ranging from the main course to desserts. In the United States, potlucks are associated with [[crockpot]] dishes, [[casserole]]s (often called [[hot dish]]es in the upper Midwest), dessert bars, and [[jello salad]]s. Traditionally, potlucks were a simple combination of dishes brought together by event attendees without a general theme. Recent times have seen the growth of themed dinners for parties or special occasions.
==See also== {{Portal|Food}} * [[Buffet]] * [[Free lunch]] * [[House concert]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commons}} {{Wiktionary}} * [http://www.straightdope.com/columns/read/1426/whats-the-origin-of-potluck What's the origin of "potluck"?]

{{about|the RCA 4-track cartridge|the Muntz 4-track cartridge|Stereo-Pak|the 8-track cartridge|8-track tape}} {{Infobox media | name = RCA tape cartridge | image = RCA Quarter Inch Tape Cartridge 2A.png | caption = Size comparison of RCA tape cartridge (right) with the more common Compact Cassette | encoding = Analog | type = [[Magnetic tape]] cartridge | capacity = 30 min per side, two sided | standard = | owner = [[RCA]] | use = Home audio recording | dimensions = 5 × 7.125 × 0.5 inches
(127 × 197 × 13 mm) | weight = | extended from = 1958 | extended to = 1964 }} The '''RCA tape cartridge''' (also known as the ''Magazine Loading Cartridge'') is a [[magnetic tape]] audio format that was designed to offer [[stereo]] quarter-inch [[reel-to-reel tape]] recording quality in a convenient format for the consumer market.{{cite web|url=http://richardhess.com/notes/formats/magnetic-media/magnetic-tapes/analog-audio/025-cartridges/ |title=Restoration Tips & Notes » 0.25" cartridges |publisher=Richardhess.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-06}} It was introduced in 1958, following four years of development. This timing coincided with the launch of the [[Stereophonic sound|stereophonic]] [[Gramophone record|phonograph record]]. It was introduced to the market by RCA in 1958.[http://museumofmagneticsoundrecording.org/images/R2R/vinAd59RCA2.jpg RCA Victor Announces Major Break-Through in Recorded Sound] The main advantage of the RCA tape cartridge over reel-to-reel machines is convenience.[https://books.google.com/books?id=CNwDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA205 Stereo Goes Back On Tape] Popular Mechanics, September 1960, P. 205 The user is not required to handle unruly tape ends and thread the tape through the machine before use, making the medium of magnetic tape more friendly to casual users. In addition, since the cartridge carries both supply and take-up reels, the cartridge does not have to be rewound before the tape is removed from the machine and stored. Because of these conveniences, the RCA tape cartridge system did see some success in schools, particularly in student language learning labs. The same design concept would later be used in the more successful [[Compact Cassette]], introduced by [[Philips]] in 1962. Similar to the Compact Cassette, the RCA cartridges are reversible so that either side can be played. An auto-reverse mechanism in some models allows the tape to run continuously. Equal to [[8-track tape]] and [[Stereo-Pak]], the tape runs at a standard speed of 3.75 [[inches per second]] (IPS).[http://www.obsoletemedia.org/rca-sound-tape-cartridge/ RCA Sound Tape Cartridge (1958 – 1964)], Museum Of Obsolete Media, retrieved 22 September 2016 This is double the speed of the Compact Cassette and half of the top speed of consumer reel-to-reel tape recorders, which usually offer both 3.75 IPS and 7.5 IPS speeds. Such consumer reel-to-reel machines are capable of superior audio performance, but only at the faster speed. The RCA tape cartridge format offers four discrete audio tracks that provide a typical playtime of 30 minutes of stereo sound per side, or double that for [[Monaural|monophonic]] sound. Some models can also play and record at 1.875 IPS, doubling playing time with a significant reduction in sound quality.[http://vintagecassettes.com/_history/history.htm Cartridges and Cassettes], Vintage Cassettes, retrieved 22 September 2016 This speed was of too low quality for music on these machines, but was acceptable for voice recording. With two interleaved stereo pairs, the track format and speed of the RCA tape cartridge is the same as that of consumer reel-to-reel stereo tape recorders run at 3.75 IPS. It is possible to dismantle the cartridge, spool the tape onto an open reel, and play it on such a machine. In fact, RCA offered an adapter for their Sound Tape Cartridge machines to enable them to both play back and record traditional reels of tape up to 5 inches in reel diameter. Unlike the Compact Cassette, the RCA tape cartridge incorporates a brake to prevent the tape hubs from moving when the cartridge is not in a player. Small slot windows extend from the tape hubs toward the outside of the cartridge so that the amount of tape visible on each spool can be seen. Despite its convenience the RCA tape cartridge was not much of a success. RCA was slow to produce machines for the home market. They were also slow to license prerecorded music tapes for home playback. Cost was also an issue, with a single cartridge costing US$4.50 in 1960 (${{Inflation|US|4.50|1960}} with inflation today) compared to a 1,200 foot (365 m) reel of tape, which cost $3.50 (${{Inflation|US|3.50|1960}} today). The format disappeared from retail stores by 1964. The physical tape width and speed of the tape and even the size of the RCA tape cartridge is similar to, though incompatible with, Sony's [[Elcaset]] system, introduced in 1976. That system also failed to achieve much market acceptance and was soon withdrawn. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://archive.org/details/Revoluti1958 Revolutionary New Triumph in Tape, an RCA promotional film] *[http://www.dianaschnuth.net/details/audio/cartridge.html RCA Cartridges: 1958 - 1964] *[http://www.videointerchange.com/audio_history.htm Audio Recording History] *[http://www.laventure.net/tourist/prezdisc_6_tapes.htm Image of a prerecorded cartridge] by [[Perez Prado]] *[[Techmoan]]: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Li699Qflv3g RetroTech: RCA Victor Tape Cartridge - A trailblazing failure], YouTube 22 September 2016 {{Audio format}} [[Category:Audio storage]] [[Category:Tape recording]] [[Category:Discontinued media formats]] [[Category:RCA brands]] [[Category:1958 in music]] [[Category:1958 in technology]] [[Category:Products introduced in 1958]]

revision.comment: Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/2605:6000:8908:93F0:E611:6568:E613:B16F|2605:6000:8908:93F0:E611:6568:E613:B16F]]: Removed Good Will - content needs to be supported by source/reference. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
seventh cascade of centrifuges increasing enrichment capacity by 25
revision.text:
The Nuclear Fuel Factory (FCN){{coord|22.504|S|44.646|W|}} is located near [[Resende, Rio de Janeiro|Resende]], [[state of Rio de Janeiro]], comprising three units, and has a production capacity of 280 tons of [[uranium]] per year. At present, FCN was modernized and produces at the Components and Assembly Unit the fuel rods and fuel elements needed for Brazilian [[nuclear reactors]]. The Reconversion and Pellets Production Unit is operating since 1999 with a capacity of 160 tons of UO2 pellets/year. The UO2 reconversion line uses the AUC process. The Nuclear Fuel Factory also produces other fuel element components, such as top and bottom nozzles, spacer grids and end plugs for export demands. Previously, [[Brazil]] supplied the uranium, which is transported to [[Canada]] where it’s converted into [[Uranium hexafluoride|hexafluoride gas]], and then to the [[United Kingdom]] for enrichment before it returns to Brazil for fabrication into fuel elements.
The unit has an in-house nuclear safety program and an external one, for environmental monitoring. A nuclear accounting system, internally implemented, required by the [[National Nuclear Energy Commission|Brazilian Nuclear Energy Commission]] (CNEN) and supervised by the [[International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)]] continuously performs a balance of the material in processing with a precision reaching tenths of milligrams.<ref>[http://www.inb.gov.br/resendeElemento.asp Sobre a INB<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In 2018 a seventh cascade of centrifuges was inaugurated, increasing enrichment capacity by 25%. This gives the plant the capacity to produce about 50% of the annual fuel requirements of [[Angra Nuclear Power Plant]] unit 1. The new cascade is the first part of a ten cascade expansion plan.<ref name=wnn-20180831>{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/Articles/Brazil-increases-uranium-enrichment-capacity |title=Brazil increases uranium enrichment capacity |publisher=World Nuclear News |date=31 August 2018 |accessdate=9 September 2018}}</ref>
==IAEA Inspections==
By late 2003 the [[International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)]] was negotiating with the Brazilian Government to ensure that the new uranium enrichment facility, due to begin operating in 2005, was properly safeguarded.
In April 2004 the Brazilian Government denied access for the [[IAEA]] inspectors to the uranium enrichment facility being built in Resende.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2004/WORLD/americas/04/04/brazil.nuclear/index.html CNN.com - Sources: Brazil blocks nuclear inspectors - Apr 4, 2004<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The [[plant]], scheduled to begin operation in October 2004, remains subject to [[IAEA]] inspections aimed at making sure it is not used for producing weapons-grade material. In February and March 2004 Brazil refused to let [[IAEA]] inspectors see equipment in the plant, citing a need to protect proprietary information. The IAEA had dispatched inspectors to [[Resende, Rio de Janeiro|Resende]] who found significant portions of the facility and its contents shielded from view. Walls had been built and coverings are draped over equipment.
By November 2004 the [[IAEA]] was able to reach an agreement in principle with the Brazilian government on a safeguards approach to verify the enrichment facilities in [[Brazil]], at the [[Resende, Rio de Janeiro|Resende]] facility.<ref>[http://asp.usatoday.com/community/utils/idmap/12538030.story USATODAY.com - Diplomats: IAEA, Brazil reach agreement<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> This approach would enable the IAEA to do credible inspections but at the same time take care of Brazil's need to protect certain commercial sensitivity inside the facility.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Portal|Brazil|Energy}} * [http://www.inb.gov.br/ INB (in Portuguese)]
[[Category:Nuclear technology]] [[Category:Nuclear energy in Brazil]]

revision.text:
[[Image:CellTowersAtCorners.gif|thumb|250px|Cell sites frequency reuse pattern in Cellular telephone network . See {{US patent|4,144,411}}]]
Network '''routing in a cellular network''' deals with the challenges of traditional [[telephony]] such as switching and call setup.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.enterprisenetworkingplanet.com/netsp/article.php/3607381/Networking-101-Understanding-Routing.htm | title=Networking and Understanding Routing | accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref>
Most [[cellular network]] routing issues in different cells can be attributed to the multiple access methods used for transmission. The location of each mobile phone must be known to reuse a given band of frequencies in different cells and forms [[space-division multiple access]] (SDMA).
==Networks== [[FDMA]] is one of the multiple access methods used in cellular networks. 50 MHz blocks of communication channel are assigned, which lie in radio frequency range and contain an equal number of uplinks (terminal to base station) and downlinks (base station to terminal).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.thenetworkencyclopedia.com/entry/frequency-division-multiple-access-fdma/ | title=Frequency Division Multiple Access (FDMA) and cellular phone technology | accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref> One or more bidirectional channels are carried by 10-90 band pairs. The digital networks additionally make use of either [[Code division multiple access|CDMA]] or [[Time-division multiple access|TDMA]] methods.
===Handover and roaming=== A special service called [[mobility management]] provides this application. Terminals (handsets) can move from one place to another during the call and therefore requires the call to be [[Handover|handed over]] from one channel to another.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://itsec.rwth-aachen.de/publications/dis_ulrike_meyer.pdf | title=Secure Roaming and Handover Procedures in Wireless Access Net works | accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref> Soft handover uses the same frequency channel.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://morse.colorado.edu/~tlen5510/text/classwebch2.html | title=Cellular systems and frequency reuse | accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref> The same terminals can operate in the same area covered by different service providers, which is known as [[roaming]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ustudy.in/node/7179 | title=Roaming and Handoff | accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Wikiversity | Routing}} * [http://compnetworking.about.com/ Networking and wireless]
{{Telecommunications-stub}}
[[Category:Mobile technology]]

{{short description|An offshore mooring buoy with connections for loading or unloading tankers}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2014}}
[[File:Whiddy Spim.jpeg|thumb|Single point mooring at [[Whiddy Island]], Ireland]] [[Image:SBM01.jpg|thumb|Single-point mooring facility off [[Puthuvype]], [[Kochi]], [[India]]]] [[Image:SBM02.jpg|thumb]] [[Image:SBM03.jpg|thumb]]
A '''Single buoy mooring''' ('''SrM''') (also known as '''single-point mooring''' or '''SPM''') is a loading [[buoy]] anchored offshore, that serves as a mooring point and interconnect for [[tanker (ship)|tankers]] loading or offloading gas or liquid products. SPMs are the link between geostatic subsea manifold connections and weathervaning tankers. They are capable of handling any tonnage ship, even [[very large crude carrier]]s (VLCC) where no alternative facility is available.
In shallow water SPMs are used to load and unload crude oil and refined products from inshore and offshore oilfields or refineries, usually through some form of storage system. These buoys are usually suitable for use by all types of oil tanker. In deep water oil fields, SPMs are usually used to load crude oil direct from the production platforms, where there are economic reasons not to run a pipeline to the shore. These moorings usually supply to dedicated tankers which can moor without assistance.<ref name="P D Handbook 1.10" />
Several types of single point mooring are in use.<ref name="P D Handbook 1.10">{{cite book|editor=Bevan, John|title=The Professional Divers's Handbook|edition=second|year=2005|publisher=Submex Ltd|location=5 Nepean Close, Alverstoke, GOSPORT, Hampshire PO12 2BH |language=English|isbn= 978-0950824260|page=41|chapter=Section 1.10}}</ref>
==Configurations== [[File:Thistle SALM.png|thumb|upright=0.3|left|Single anchor leg mooring]] A commonly used configuration is the catenary anchor leg mooring (CALM), which can be capable of handling very large crude carriers. This configuration uses six or eight heavy anchor chains placed radially around the buoy, of a tonnage to suit the designed load, each about {{convert|350|m|ft}} long, and attached to an anchor or pile to provide the required holding power. The anchor chains are pre-tensioned to ensure that the buoy is held in position above the PLEM. As the load from the tanker is applied, the heavy chains on the far side straighten and lift off the seabed to apply the balancing load. Under full design load there is still some {{convert|27|m|ft}} of chain lying on the bottom. The flexible hose riser may be in one of three basic configurations, all designed to accommodate tidal depth variation and lateral displacement due to mooring loads. In all cases the hose curvature changes to accommodate lateral and vertical movement of the buoy, and the hoses are supported at near neutral buoyancy by floats along the length. These are:<ref name="P D Handbook 1.10" /> *Chinese lantern, in which two to four mirror symmetrical hoses connect the PLEM with the buoy, with the convexity of the curve facing radially outwards. *Lazy-S, in which the riser hose leaves the PLEM at a steep angle, then flattens out before gradually curving upwards to meet the buoy approximately vertically, in a flattened S-curve. *Steep-S, in which the hose first rises roughly vertically to a submerged float, before making a sharp bend downwards followed by a slow curve through horizontal to a vertical attachment to the buoy.
Less commonly used configurations include: *Single anchor leg mooring (SALM), which can be used in both shallow and deep water.<ref name="P D Handbook 1.10" /> see [[Thistle SALM]] as an example. *Vertical anchor leg mooring, which is seldom used.<ref name="P D Handbook 1.10" /> *Two types of single point mooring tower: :*Jacket type, which has a jacket piled to the seabed with a turntable on top which carries the mooring gear and pipework<ref name="P D Handbook 1.10" /> :*Spring pile type, which has steel pipe risers in the structure<ref name="P D Handbook 1.10" /> *Exposed location single buoy mooring (ELSBM). This configuration stores the mooring line and cargo hose on drums when not in use. Suitable for use in rough conditions<ref name="P D Handbook 1.10" /> *Articulated loading platform (ALP). Also suited for rough conditions.<ref name="P D Handbook 1.10" />
==Parts== There are four groups of parts in the total mooring system: the body of the buoy, mooring and anchoring elements, product transfer system and other components.
===Buoy body=== The buoy body may be supported on static legs attached to the seabed, with a rotating part above water level connected to the (off)loading tanker. The two sections are linked by a roller bearing, referred to as the "main bearing". Alternatively the buoy body may be held in place by multiple radiating anchor chains. The moored tanker can freely weather vane around the buoy and find a stable position due to this arrangement.
===Mooring and anchoring parts=== Moorings fix the buoy to the sea bed. Buoy design must account for the behaviour of the buoy given applicable wind, wave and current conditions and tanker tonnages. This determines the optimum mooring arrangement and size of the various mooring leg components. Anchoring points are greatly dependent on local soil condition.<ref name="IALA Guideline 1066" />
====Mooring components==== *Anchors or piles - To connect the mooring to the seabed<ref name="IALA Guideline 1066" /> *Sinker or anchor chain joint to buoy (SPM)<ref name="IALA Guideline 1066" /> *Anchor chain<ref name="IALA Guideline 1066" /> *Chain stoppers - To connect the chains to the buoy<ref name="IALA Guideline 1066">IALA Guideline 1066 - The Design of FLoating Aid to Navigation Moorings - May 2009 - Revised June 2010</ref>
====Hawser arrangement==== A tanker is moored to a buoy by means of a hawser arrangement. [[Oil Companies International Marine Forum]] (OCIMF) standards are available for mooring systems.
The hawser arrangement usually consist of nylon rope, which is shackled to an integrated mooring uni-joint on the buoy deck. At the tanker end of the hawser, a chafe chain is connected to prevent damage from the tanker fairlead. A load pin can be applied to the mooring uni-joint on the buoy deck to measure hawser loads.
Hawser systems use either one or two ropes depending on the largest tonnage of vessel which would be moored to the buoy. The ropes would either be single-leg or grommet leg type ropes. These are usually connected to an OCIMF chafe chain on the export tanker side (either type A or B depending on the maximum tonnage of the tanker and the mooring loads). This chafe chain would then be held in the chain stopper on board the export tanker.
A basic hawser system would consist of the following (working from the buoy outwards):
Buoy-side shackle and bridle assembly for connection to the padeye on the buoy; Mooring hawser shackle; Mooring hawser; Chafe chain assembly; Support buoy; Pick-up / messenger lines; Marker buoy for retrieval from the water.
Under OCIMF recommendations, the hawser arrangement would normally be purchased as a full assembly from a manufacturer.
===Product transfer system === The heart of each buoy is the product transfer system. From a geostatic location, e.g. a [[pipeline end manifold]] (PLEM) located on the seabed, this system transfers products to the offtake tanker.
The basic product transfer system components are: *Flexible subsea hoses, generally referred to as “risers” *Floating hose string(s) *Marine Breakaway Coupling *Product swivel, valves and piping
====Risers==== The risers are flexible hoses that connect the subsea piping to the buoy. Configuration of these risers can vary depending on water depth, sea conditions, buoy motions, etc.
====Floating hose string==== Floating hose string(s) connect the buoy to the offloading tanker. The hose string can be equipped with a breakaway coupling to prevent rupture of hoses/hawser and subsequent oil spills.
====Product swivel ==== The product swivel is the connection between the geostatic and the rotating parts of the buoy. The swivel enables an offloading tanker to rotate with respect to the mooring buoy. Product swivels range in size depending on the capacity of attached piping and risers. Product swivels can provide one or several independent paths for fluids, gases, electrical signals or power. Swivels are equipped with a multiple seal arrangement to minimise the possibility of leakage of product into the environment.
===Other components=== Other possible components of SPMs are: *A boat landing, providing access to the buoy deck, *Fendering to protect the buoy, *Lifting and handling equipment to aid materials handling, *Navigational aids for maritime visibility, and fog horn to keep moving vessel alert. *An electrical subsystem to enable valve operation and to power navigation aids or other equipment.
==See also== * {{annotated link|International Association of Marine Aids to Navigation and Lighthouse Authorities|abbreviation=IALA}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commonscat|Single buoy mooring}} * [http://www.iala-aism.org/ International Association of Lighthouse Authorities (IALA) official site]

{{Orphan|date=September 2015}}
{{Infobox company | name = SpeechSchool.TV | logo = SpeechSchool.tv-Logo.png | type = Private |area_served = Worldwide | foundation = Auckland, New Zealand 2009 | location_city = | location_country = London, United Kingdom and Auckland, New Zealand | key_people = | industry = [[Online Education]] | products = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.speechschool.tv|www.speechschool.tv}} }} '''SpeechSchool.TV''' is an online speech training service based in [[New Zealand]] and the [[United Kingdom]]. It provides a subscription based Internet [[TV channel]] to provide a Standard [[English accent]] training service to students worldwide. It was founded in 2009 for the purpose of teaching the English accent to foreign students and others who are interested in improving their accent. It has won the ''Technium Challenge award'' for New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web|title=Battle of the bright ideas|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10631741|publisher=[[nzherald.co.nz]]|accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Technium Challenge triumph for SpeechSchool|url=http://www.btob.co.nz/article/technium-challenge-triumph-speechschool|publisher=btob.co.nz|accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=SpeechSchool wins Technium Challenge|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/BU1008/S00997/speechschool-wins-technium-challenge.htm|publisher=[[scoop.co.nz]]|accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=TV Speech School Wins Top Prize|url=http://www.voxy.co.nz/lifestyle/tv-speech-school-wins-top-prize/5/60999|publisher=voxy.co.nz|accessdate=29 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Hague wants to build on trust|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10701018|publisher=nzherald.co.nz|accessdate=30 June 2014}}</ref>
The company provides two different courses in speech training; ''The Master Speaker English Accent programme'' which is focused on [[accent reduction]] to help develop clear English speaking skills without mumbling or [[stuttering]], and the other is ''The Master Communicator programme'' to help develop presentation, confidence and [[public speaking]] skills.<ref>{{cite web|title=Is your accent holding you back? |url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Is-your-accent-holding-you-back/tabid/572/articleID/146515/Default.aspx |publisher=[[3news.co.nz]] |accessdate=30 June 2014 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130405131958/http://www.3news.co.nz/Is-your-accent-holding-you-back/tabid/572/articleID/146515/Default.aspx |archivedate=April 5, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Launch Pad 2010 selects three leading startups|url=http://www.computerworld.co.nz/article/490128/launch_pad_2010_selects_three_leading_startups/|publisher=computerworld.co.nz|accessdate=1 July 2014}}</ref>
==References== <references/>

revision.text:
[[File:Parking lot stormwater detention system.jpg|thumb|A stormwater detention system during installation beneath a parking lot]]
A '''stormwater detention vault''' is an underground structure designed to manage excess [[stormwater]] [[surface runoff|runoff]] on a developed site, often in an urban setting. This type of [[Best management practice for water pollution|best management practice]] may be selected when there is insufficient space on the site to [[infiltration basin|infiltrate]] the runoff or build a surface facility such as a [[detention basin]] or [[retention basin]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=United States Department of Transportation. Federal Highway Administration|place=Washington, D.C.|url=http://www.fhwa.dot.gov/environment/ultraurb/3fs6.htm |title=Stormwater Best Management Practices in an Ultra-Urban Setting: Selection and Monitoring|work=Fact Sheet – Detention Tanks and Vaults|date=May 2002}}</ref>
Detention vaults manage stormwater ''quantity'' flowing to nearby [[surface water]]s. They help prevent [[flood]]ing and can reduce [[erosion#Water|erosion]] in rivers and streams. They do not provide treatment to improve [[water quality]],<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Atlanta Regional Commission|place=Atlanta, GA|url=http://documents.atlantaregional.com/gastormwater/GSMMVol2.pdf|title=Georgia Stormwater Management Manual. Section 3.4.3: Underground Detention|date=August 2001}}</ref> though some are attached to a [[media filter]] bank to remove pollutants.
==Design and installation== Underground stormwater detention allows for high volume storage of runoff in a small footprint area. The storage vessels can be made from a variety of materials, including corrugated metal [[pipe (material)|pipe]], aluminum, steel, plastic, fiberglass, [[Precast concrete|pre-cast]] or poured-in-place [[concrete]].<ref name="Duluth">{{cite web|publisher=City of Duluth, Minnesota|url=http://www.lakesuperiorstreams.org/stormwater/toolkit/underground.html|title=Tools for Stormwater Management: Underground Storage|accessdate=April 15, 2008}}</ref>
The vault is typically buried under a [[parking lot]] or other open land on the site. In the latter case, this underground vault may be preferable to a surface [[detention pond]] if other uses are intended for the land (e.g. a pedestrian plaza or park). In other situations, a vault is used because installing a pond might pose other problems, such as attracting unwanted [[waterfowl]] or other animals. In some sites, a vault may be installed in the basement of a building, such as a parking garage.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=United States Environmental Protection Agency|url=http://www.epa.gov/owmitnet/mtb/runoff.pdf|title=Storm Water Technology Fact Sheet: On-Site Underground Retention/Detention|date=September 2001|id=EPA-832-F-01-005}}</ref> Tunnels may be bored to serve as detention vaults.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://wfpl.org/a-sewer-tunnel-and-a-brief-geologic-history-of-louisville/|title=MSD's New Sewer Tunnel Offers A Brief Geologic History Of Louisville|last=Velzer|first=Ryan Van|date=2018-08-15|work=89.3 WFPL News Louisville|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en-US}}</ref> Tunnels may be cheaper than basins, as they do not require pumps to move the water.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/2018/07/30/louisville-msd-cancels-basin-project-near-cherokee-park/862392002/|title=MSD was digging a huge basin near Jim Porter's but has abandoned the plan|work=The Courier-Journal|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en}}</ref>
The outlet is generally a restricted-flow drain from the detention vessel, with a weir for containing detritus.<ref name="Duluth"/> Detention vessels delay water's delivery downstream, and possibly creates a later water level peak post-rainfall. It is important to consider timing of water release and the types of reservoirs feeding a waterway.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://documents.atlantaregional.com/gastormwater/GSMMVol1.pdf | title=Georgia Stormwater Management Manual | publisher=Atlanta Regional Commission | date=August 2001 | accessdate=August 4, 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Best management practice for water pollution]] * [[Detention basin]] * [[Retention basin]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Stormwater structures}} {{Sewerage}}
[[Category:Environmental engineering]] [[Category:Hydraulic engineering]] [[Category:Hydrology]] [[Category:Stormwater management]]

'''Tech mining''' or '''technology mining''' refers to applying [[text mining]] methods to technical documents. For patent analysis purposes, it is named ‘'''patent mining'''’. Porter, as one of the pioneers in technology mining, defined ‘tech mining’ in his book<ref>{{cite book|title=Tech Mining: Exploiting New Technologies for Competitive Advantage|last1=Porter|first1=Alan L.|last2=Cunninghum|first2=Scott W.|date=2004|publisher=Wiley|isbn=978-0-471-47567-5}}</ref> as follows: “the application of text mining tools to science and technology information, informed by understanding of technological innovation processes.” Therefore, tech mining has two significant characteristics: 1) using ‘text mining tools’, 2) applying these tools to ‘technology management’. Also, technology mining can be considered as one of [[technology intelligence]] branches.
== Applications == Technology mining have many applications including R&D portfolio selection, R&D project initiation, [[new product development]], strategic technology planning, [[technology roadmapping]], etc.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Porter|first=Alan L.|date=2005|title=Tech Mining|url=https://www.thevantagepoint.com/resources/articles/CI%20Jan-Feb%2005%20Porter.pdf|journal=Competitive Intelligence Magazine|volume=8|pages=30-37|via=}}</ref> Tech miner should communicate closely with target users what technological issue they have, and how they want to address the issues. The number of published papers and the number of citations in technology mining area illustrates a hyperbolically progress; there is a jump in the number of publications after 2005 and a huge rise in the number of citations after 2012.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Madani|first=Farshad|date=2015|title=‘Technology Mining’ bibliometrics analysis: applying network analysis and cluster analysis|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11192-015-1685-4|journal=Scientometrics|volume=105|pages=323–335|via=}}</ref>
== External Links == [http://www.gtmconference.org Global TechMining Conference]
[http://www.techmining.com Tech Mining website]
[https://www.thevantagepoint.com VantagePoint]
[http://www.vpinstitute.org VantagePoint Institute website]

{{Infobox company |company_name = The Art of Shaving |company_logo = |company_type = [[Subsidiary]] |founded = 1996 |founders = Eric Malka
Myriam Zaoui |location_city = [[New York City, New York]] |location_country = [[United States|U.S.]] |key_people = |num_employees = |industry = Shaving products |products = |revenue = |parent = [[Procter & Gamble]]
(2009–present) |operating_income = |homepage = {{URL|http://www.theartofshaving.com}} }} '''The Art of Shaving''' is a [[United States]] retail business of high-end men's shaving and skin care accessories. The first store was founded by Eric Malka and Myriam Zaoui in Manhattan in 1996.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/05/business/05pursuits.html|title=The Kind of Shave You Can't Get at Home|author=Harry Hunt III|accessdate=2011-04-24|work=The New York Times|date=2005-11-05}} The store was successful and opened a second shop on Madison Avenue. The brand developed a line of natural shaving products.{{cite web|url=http://www.theartofshaving.com/taos6/history.php|title=The Art of Shaving - History|accessdate=2008-12-27 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080802155645/http://www.theartofshaving.com/taos6/history.php |archivedate = 2008-08-02}} The company operates 17 stores across the United States. 10 new stores were opened in 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.theartofshaving.com/taos6/taos-shops.php|title=The Art of Shaving - Shops|accessdate=2008-12-27}} The company entered a partnership with razor company [[Global Gillette|Gillette]] with some The Art of Shaving franchises owned by Gillette.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/lifestyle/fashion/articles/2008/03/27/looking_good_dude_head_to_toe/|title=Looking good, dude, head to toe|last=Laban|first=Linda|date=2008-03-27|publisher=Boston Globe|accessdate=2008-12-27}} [[Procter & Gamble]] purchased The Art of Shaving in 2009.{{Cite web| title = P&G buys high-end brand The Art of Shaving| work = Reuters| date = 2009-06-03| accessdate = 2018-08-16| url = https://www.reuters.com/article/procter-idUSN036942020090603}}{{Cite web| title = Art of Shaving Promoted as a Brotherhood Brand| last = Newman | first = Andrew Adam| work = [[The New York Times]]| date = 17 November 2010| accessdate = 2018-08-16| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/18/business/media/18adco.html}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *{{official|http://www.theartofshaving.com}} {{Procter & Gamble}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Art of Shaving}} {{US-retail-company-stub}} [[Category:Procter & Gamble brands]] [[Category:Personal care brands]]
