revision.text:
{{cleanup|date=November 2010}}
As the devices continue to shrink further into the sub-100 nm range following the trend predicted by [[Moore’s law]], the topic of thermal properties and transport in such nanoscale devices becomes increasingly important. Display of great potential by [[nanostructure]]s for [[Thermoelectricity|thermoelectric]] applications also motivates the studies of thermal transport in such devices.<ref name = Ju>{{Cite journal|last = Ju | year = 2005|title = Phonon Heat Transport in Silicon Nanostructures|journal = Applied Physics Letters|volume = 87|pages = 153106|doi = 10.1063/1.2089178|first1 = Y. Sungtaek|bibcode = 2005ApPhL..87o3106J|issue = 15 }}</ref> These fields, however, generate two contradictory demands: high [[thermal conductivity]] to deal with heating issues in sub-100 nm devices and low thermal conductivity for thermoelectric applications. These issues can be addressed with [[phonon]] engineering, once nanoscale thermal behaviors have been studied and understood.<ref name=Balandin2000>{{Cite web| last = Balandin| first = A| year = 2000| title = Thermal Properties of Semiconductor Low-Dimensional Structures| url = http://ndl.ee.ucr.edu/therma10.pdf| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100618020210/http://ndl.ee.ucr.edu/therma10.pdf| archivedate = 2010-06-18| df = }}</ref>
==The effect of the limited length of structure== In general two carrier types can contribute to thermal conductivity - [[electrons]] and [[phonons]]. In nanostructures phonons usually dominate and the phonon properties of the structure become of a particular importance for thermal conductivity.<ref name=Ju /><ref name=Hone>{{Cite journal | last = Hone | year = 2000 | title = Electrical and thermal transport properties of magnetically aligned single wall carbon nanotube films|journal = Applied Physics Letters|volume = 77| issue = 5| pages = 666–668 |doi = 10.1063/1.127079 | first1 = J. | last2 = Llaguno | first2 = M. C. | last3 = Nemes | first3 = N. M. | last4 = Johnson | first4 = A. T. | last5 = Fischer | first5 = J. E. | last6 = Walters | first6 = D. A. | last7 = Casavant | first7 = M. J. | last8 = Schmidt | first8 = J. | last9 = Smalley | first9 = R. E.|bibcode = 2000ApPhL..77..666H }}</ref><ref name=Nika2009>{{Cite journal |last = Nika|year = 2009 | title = Phonon thermal conduction in graphene: Role of Umklapp and edge roughness scattering | journal = Physical Review B | volume = 79| pages = 155413 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevB.79.155413 |first1 = D. |last2 = Pokatilov |first2 = E. |last3 = Askerov |first3 = A. |last4 = Balandin |first4 = A.|bibcode = 2009PhRvB..79o5413N |issue = 15 }}</ref> These phonon properties include: phonon [[group velocity]], [[phonon scattering]] mechanisms, [[heat capacity]], [[Grüneisen parameter]]. Unlike bulk materials, nanoscale devices have thermal properties which are complicated by boundary effects due to small size. It has been shown that in some cases phonon-boundary scattering effects dominate the thermal conduction processes, reducing thermal conductivity.<ref name=Ju /><ref name= Li>{{cite journal|title=Thermal conductivity of individual silicon nanowires|journal=Applied Physics Letters|year=2003|first=D. |last=Li|author2=Y. Wu |author3=P. Kim |author4=L. Shi |author5=P. Yang |author6=A. Majumdar |volume=83|issue=14|pages=2934–6|doi= 10.1063/1.1616981|bibcode = 2003ApPhL..83.2934L }}</ref>
Depending on the nanostructure size, the phonon [[mean free path]] values (Λ) may be comparable or larger than the object size, <math>L</math>. When <math>L</math> is larger than the phonon mean free path, [[Umklapp scattering]] process limits thermal conductivity (regime of diffusive thermal conductivity). When <math>L</math> is comparable to or smaller than the mean free path (which is of the order 1 µm for carbon nanostructures<ref name= Ghosh> {{cite journal |title=Extremely high thermal conductivity of graphene: Prospects for thermal management applications in nanoelectronic circuits|journal=Applied Physics Letters |year=2008 |first=S. |last=Ghosh |volume=92|pages=151911 |doi= 10.1063/1.2907977 |last2=Calizo |first2=I. |last3=Teweldebrhan |first3=D. |last4=Pokatilov |first4=E. P. |last5=Nika |first5=D. L. |last6=Balandin |first6=A. A. |last7=Bao |first7=W. |last8=Miao |first8=F. |last9=Lau |first9=C. N.|bibcode = 2008ApPhL..92o1911G |issue=15 |displayauthors=1 }}</ref>), the continuous energy model used for bulk materials no longer applies and nonlocal and nonequilibrium aspects to [[heat transfer]] also need to be considered.<ref name=Ju /> In this case phonons in defectless structure could propagate without scattering and thermal conductivity becomes ballistic (similar to [[ballistic conduction|ballistic conductivity]]). More severe changes in thermal behavior are observed when the feature size <math>L</math> shrinks further down to the wavelength of phonons.<ref name=Balandin2002>{{Cite journal | last = Balandin| year = 2002 | title = Nanoscale thermal management | journal = Potentials, IEEE | volume = 21| issue = 1 | pages = 11–15 | doi = 10.1109/45.985321 | first1 = A.A.}}</ref>
==Nanowires==
===Thermal conductivity measurements=== The first measurement of thermal conductivity in silicon nanowires was published in 2003.<ref name=Li /> Two important features were pointed out: 1) The measured thermal conductivities are significantly lower than that of the bulk Si and, as the wire diameter is decreased, the corresponding thermal conductivity is reduced. 2) As the wire diameter is reduced, the phonon boundary scattering dominates over phonon–phonon [[Umklapp scattering]], which decreases the thermal conductivity with an increase in temperature.
For 56 nm and 115 nm wires ''k ~ T<sup>3</sup>'' dependence was observed, while for 37 nm wire ''k ~ T<sup>2</sup>'' dependence and for 22 nm wire ''k ~ T'' dependence were observed. Chen ''et al.'' <ref name = RChen>{{cite journal|title=Thermal Conductance of Thin Silicon Nanowires|journal=Phys. Rev. Lett.|year=2008|first=R|last=Chen|author2=A. Hochbaum |author3=P. Murphy |author4=J. Moore |author5=P. Yang |author6=A. Majumdar |volume=101|pages=105501|doi= 10.1103/PhysRevLett.101.105501|pmid=18851223|issue=10|bibcode=2008PhRvL.101j5501C}}</ref> has shown that the one-dimensional cross-over for 20 nm Si nanowire occurs around 8K, while the phenomenon was observed for temperature values greater than 20K. Therefore, the reason of such behaviour is not in the confinement experienced by phonons so that three-dimensional structures display two-dimensional or one-dimensional behavior.
===Theoretical models for nanowires===
====Different phonon modes contribution to thermal conductivity==== Assuming that Boltzmann transport equation is valid, thermal conductivity can be written as:
:<math>k=\frac{1}{3}Cv_g\Lambda=\frac{1}{3}Cv_g^2\tau</math>
where C is the heat capacity, v<sub>g</sub> is the group velocity and <math>\tau</math> is the relaxation time. Note that this assumption breaks down when the dimensions of the system are comparable to or smaller than the wavelength of the phonons responsible for thermal transport. In our case, phonon wavelengths are generally in the 1 nm range <ref name=EP>{{Cite web |last = Pop |first = Eric |year = 2009 |title = Lecture 8 - Thermal Conductivity |url = http://poplab.ece.illinois.edu/files/ece598/L5L6L7_Phonons.pdf}}</ref> and the nanowires under consideration are within tens of nanometers range, the assumption is valid.
Different phonon mode contributions to heat conduction can be extracted from analysis of the experimental data for silicon nanowires of different diameters <ref name=Ju /> to extract the ''C·v<sub>g</sub>'' product for analysis. It was shown that all phonon modes contributing to thermal transport are excited well below the Si [[Debye temperature]] (645 K).
From the thermal conductivity equation, one can write the product ''C·v<sub>g</sub>'' for each isotropic phonon branch ''i''.
:<math>(Cv_g)_i=\frac{k_B^4 T^3}{2\hbar^3\pi^2}\int \frac{1}{v_{p,i}^2}\left[\frac{x^4 \exp(x)}{(\exp(x)-1)^2}\right]\,dx </math>
where <math>x = h\omega/k_{B}T</math> and <math>v_{p,i}</math> is the phonon phase velocity, which is less sensitive to phonon dispersions than the group velocity ''v<sub>g</sub>''.
Many models of phonon thermal transport ignores the effects of transverse acoustic phonons (TA) at high frequency due to their small group velocity. (Optical phonon contributions are also ignored for the same reason.) However, upper branch of TA phonons have non-zero group velocity at the Brillouin zone boundary along the Γ-Κ direction and, in fact, behave similarly to the longitudinal acoustic phonons (LA) and can contribute to the heat transport.
Then, the possible phonon modes contributing to heat conduction are both LA and TA phonons at low and high frequencies. Using the corresponding dispersion curves, the ''C·v<sub>g</sub>'' product can then be calculated and fitted to the experimental data. The best fit was found when contribution of high-frequency TA phonons is accounted as 70% of the product at room temperature. The remaining 30% is contributed by the LA and TA phonons at low-frequency.
====Using complete phonon dispersions==== Thermal conductivity in nanowires can be computed based on complete phonon dispersions instead of the linearlized dispersion relations commonly used to calculate thermal conductivity in bulk materials.<ref name=Mingo>{{cite journal|title=Calculation of Si nanowire thermal conductivity using complete phonon dispersion relations|journal=Phys. Rev. B|year=2003|first=N.|last=Mingo|volume=68|issue=11|pages=113308–12|doi= 10.1103/PhysRevB.68.113308|arxiv = cond-mat/0308587 |bibcode = 2003PhRvB..68k3308M |url=https://zenodo.org/record/1233747/files/article.pdf}}</ref>
Assuming the phonon transport is diffusive and Boltzmann transport equation (BTE) is valid, nanowire [[Thermal conductivity#Conductance|thermal conductance]] ''G(T)'' can be defined as:
:<math> G(T) \simeq \sum_{\alpha}{\int{ \frac{\lambda_a(k_z)}{L} \frac{\hbar \omega_{\alpha}(k_z)}{2\pi} \frac{df_b}{dT}v_z(\alpha,k_z)dk_z}} </math>
where the variable α represents discrete quantum numbers associated with sub-bands found in one-dimensional phonon dispersion relations, ''f<sub>B</sub>'' represents the Bose-Einstein distribution, ''v<sub>z</sub>'' is the phonon velocity in the ''z'' direction and λ is the phonon relaxation length along the direction of the wire length. [[Thermal conductivity]] is then expressed as:
:<math>k(T)=\frac{1}{S} \sum{\alpha} {\int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{a_z}} \lambda_\alpha (k_z) \frac{\hbar\omega_\alpha (k_z)}{2\pi}\frac{df_B}{dT}v_z(\alpha,k_z)\, dk_z}</math>
where ''S'' is the cross sectional area of the wire, ''a<sub>z</sub>'' is the lattice constant.
It was shown <ref name=Mingo /> that, using this formula and atomistically computed phonon dispersions (with [[interatomic potential]]s developed in <ref name =Harrison>{{cite book |last = Harrison |first = Walter A. |title = Electronic Structure and the Properties of Solids: The Physics of the Chemical Bond |publisher = [[Dover Publications]] |year = 1989 |url = https://www.amazon.ca/exec/obidos/redirect?tag=citeulike09-20\&path=ASIN/0486660214 |isbn = 0-486-66021-4}}</ref>), it is possible to predictively calculate lattice thermal conductivity curves for nanowires, in good agreement with experiments. On the other hand, it was not possible to obtain correct results with the approximated Callaway formula.<ref name= Callaway>{{cite journal|title=Model for Lattice Thermal Conductivity at Low Temperatures|journal=Phys. Rev. Lett.|year=1959|first=J.|last=Callaway|volume=113|issue=4|pages=1046–51|doi= 10.1103/PhysRev.113.1046|bibcode = 1959PhRv..113.1046C }}</ref> These results are expected to apply to ”nanowhiskers” for which phonon confinement effects are unimportant. Si nanowires wider than ~35 nm are within this category.<ref name=Mingo />
====Very thin nanowires==== For large diameter nanowires, theoretical models assuming the nanowire diameters are comparable to the mean free path and that the mean free path is independent of phonon frequency have been able to closely match the experimental results. But for very thin nanowires whose dimensions are comparable to the dominant phonon wavelength, a new model is required. The study in <ref name=RChen/> has shown that in such cases, the phonon-boundary scattering is dependent on frequency. The new mean free path is then should be used:
:<math> l^{-1} = B \left(\frac{h}{d}\right)^2 \frac{1}{d} \left(\frac{\omega}{\omega_D}\right)^2N(\omega) </math>
Here, ''l'' is the mean free path (same as Λ). The parameter ''h'' is length scale associated with the disordered region, ''d'' is the diameter, ''N(ω)'' is number of modes at frequency ω, and ''B'' is a constant related to the disorder region.<ref name=RChen/>
Thermal conductance is then calculated using the Landauer formula:
:<math> G(T) = \int\limits_0^{\infty} \frac{\mathrm{d}\omega}{2 \pi} \, \left( \frac{N_1(\omega)}{1+L/l(\omega)} + \frac{N_2(\omega)}{1+L/d} \right) \frac{\hbar^2 \omega^2}{k_B T^2} \frac{\exp(\hbar \omega / k_B T)}{[\exp(\hbar\omega / k_BT) - 1]^2} </math>
==Carbon nanotubes== As nanoscale graphitic structures, [[carbon nanotube]]s are of great interest for their thermal properties. The low-temperature specific heat and thermal conductivity show direct evidence of 1-D quantization of the phonon [[band structure]]. Modeling of the low-temperature specific heat allows determination of the on-tube phonon velocity, the splitting of phonon subbands on a single tube, and the interaction between neighboring tubes in a bundle.
===Thermal conductivity measurements=== Measurements show a single-wall carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) room-temperature thermal conductivity about 3500 W/(m·K),<ref name="Pop"> {{cite journal |title = Thermal conductance of an individual single-wall carbon nanotube above room temperature |journal=Nano Letters |date=2005-12-22 |last=Pop |first=Eric |last2 = Mann |first2 = David |last3 = Wang |first3 = Qian |last4 = Goodson |first4 = Kenneth |last5 = Dai |first5 = Hongjie | author5-link = Hongjie Dai |volume=6 |issue=1 |pages= 96–100 |doi =10.1021/nl052145f |pmid = 16402794|arxiv = cond-mat/0512624 |bibcode = 2006NanoL...6...96P |displayauthors=1 }}</ref> and over 3000 W/(m·K) for individual multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs).<ref name="Kim"> {{cite journal |title = Thermal transport measurements of individual multiwalled nanotubes |journal=Physical Review Letters |date=2001-06-01 |first=P. |last=Kim |last2 = Shi |first2 = L. |last3 = Majumdar |first3 = A. |last4 = McEuen |first4 = P. L. |volume=87 |issue = 21 |pages= 215502–215506 |doi =10.1103/PhysRevLett.87.215502 |pmid=11736348 |bibcode=2001PhRvL..87u5502K|arxiv = cond-mat/0106578 |displayauthors=1 }}</ref> It is difficult to replicate these properties on the macroscale due to imperfect contact between individual CNTs, and so tangible objects from CNTs such as films or fibres have reached only up to 1500 W/(m·K)<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Koziol|first=Krzysztof K.|last2=Janas|first2=Dawid|last3=Brown|first3=Elisabetta|last4=Hao|first4=Ling|title=Thermal properties of continuously spun carbon nanotube fibres|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1386947716310153|journal=Physica E: Low-dimensional Systems and Nanostructures|doi=10.1016/j.physe.2016.12.011|bibcode=2017PhyE...88..104K}}</ref> so far. Addition of nanotubes to epoxy resin can double the thermal conductivity for a loading of only 1%, showing that nanotube composite materials may be useful for thermal management applications.
===Theoretical models for nanotubes=== Thermal conductivity in CNT is mainly due to phonons rather than electrons <ref name=Hone/> so the [[Wiedemann–Franz law]] is not applicable.
In general, the thermal conductivity is a tensor quality, but for this discussion, it is only important to consider the diagonal elements:
:<math>k_{zz} = \sum C{v_z}^2\tau</math>
where C is the specific heat, and ''v<sub>z</sub>'' and <math>\tau</math> are the group velocity and [[phonon scattering|relaxation time]] of a given phonon state.
At low temperatures (T is far less than Debye temperature), the relaxation time is determined by scattering of fixed impurities, defects, sample boundaries, etc. and is roughly constant. Therefore, in ordinary materials, the low-temperature thermal conductivity has the same temperature dependence as the specific heat. However, in anisotropic materials, this relationship does not strictly hold. Because the contribution of each state is weighted by the scattering time and the square of the velocity, the thermal conductivity preferentially samples states with large velocity and scattering time. For instance, in graphite, the thermal conductivity parallel to the [[basal plane]]s is only weakly dependent on the interlayer phonons. In SWNT bundles, it is likely that ''k(T)'' depends only on the on-tube phonons, rather than the intertube modes.
Thermal conductivity is of particular interest in low-dimensional systems. For CNT, represented as 1-D ballistic electronic channel, the electronic conductance is quantized, with a universal value of
:<math>G_0 = \frac{2e^2}{h} </math>
Similarly, for a single ballistic 1-D channel, the thermal conductance is independent of materials parameters, and there exists a [[quantum of thermal conductance]], which is linear in temperature:<ref name=Brown> {{cite journal |title = Ballistic thermal and electrical conductance measurements on individual multiwall carbon nanotubes |journal=Applied Physics Letters |year=2005 |first=E. |last=Brown |volume=87 |pages=023107 |doi = 10.1063/1.1993768 |last2 = Hao |first2 = Ling |last3 = Gallop |first3 = John C. |last4 = MacFarlane |first4 = John C.|bibcode = 2005ApPhL..87b3107B |issue = 2 |displayauthors=1 }}</ref>
:<math>G_{th} = \frac{\pi^2 {k_B}^2 T}{3h} </math>
Possible conditions for observation of this quantum were examined by Rego and Kirczenow.<ref name=Rego>{{cite journal|title=Quantized thermal conductance of dielectric quantum wires|journal=Phys. Rev. Lett.|year=1998|first=L.|last=Rego|author2=G. Kirczenow |volume=81|issue=1|pages=232–5|doi= 10.1103/PhysRevLett.81.232|bibcode=1998PhRvL..81..232R|arxiv = cond-mat/9801238 }}</ref> In 1999, [[Keith Schwab]], Erik Henriksen, John Worlock, and [[Michael Roukes]] carried out a series of experimental measurements that enabled first observation of the thermal conductance quantum.<ref name=Schwab>{{cite journal|title=Measurement of the quantum of thermal conductance|journal=Letters to Nature|year=2000|first=K.|last=Schwab|author2=E. A. Henriksen |author3=J. M. Worlock |author4=M. L. Roukes |volume=404|pages=974–7|doi=10.1038/35010065|pmid=10801121|issue=6781|bibcode=2000Natur.404..974S}}</ref> The measurements employed suspended nanostructures coupled to sensitive dc SQUID measurement devices. In 2008, a colorized electron micrograph of one of the Caltech devices was acquired for the permanent collection of the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in New York.
At high temperatures, three-phonon Umklapp scattering begins to limit the phonon relaxation time. Therefore, the phonon thermal conductivity displays a peak and decreases with increasing temperature. Umklapp scattering requires production of a phonon beyond the Brillouin zone boundary; because of the high Debye temperature of diamond and graphite, the peak in the thermal conductivity of these materials is near 100 K, significantly higher than for most other materials. In less crystalline forms of graphite, such as carbon fibers, the peak in ''k(T)'' occurs at higher temperatures, because defect scattering remains dominant over Umklapp scattering to higher temperature.<ref name=Heremans>{{cite journal|title=Thermal-conductivity and thermopower of vapor-grown graphite|journal=Phys. Rev. B|year=1985|first=J.|last=Heremans|author2=C. Beetz |volume=32|issue=4|pages=1981–6|doi= 10.1103/PhysRevB.32.1981|bibcode = 1985PhRvB..32.1981H }}</ref> In low-dimensional systems, it is difficult to conserve both energy and momentum for Umklapp processes,<ref name= Peierls>{{cite book|last = Peierls|first = R. E.|title = Quantum Theory of Solids|publisher = Oxford University Press|year = 1955|location = London}}</ref> and so it may be possible that Umklapp scattering is suppressed in nanotubes relative to 2-D or 3-D forms of carbon.
Berber ''et al.''<ref name="Berber">{{cite journal|title=Unusually high thermal conductivity of carbon nanotubes|journal=Physical Review Letters |date=2000-02-23|last=Berber |first=Savas |last2 = Kwon |first2 = Young-Kyun |last3 = Tománek |first3 = David |volume=84|issue=20|pages=4613–4616|doi= 10.1103/PhysRevLett.84.4613|pmid=10990753 |bibcode=2000PhRvL..84.4613B|arxiv = cond-mat/0002414 }}</ref> have calculated the phonon thermal conductivity of isolated nanotubes. The value ''k(T)'' peaks near 100 K, and then decreases with increasing temperature. The value of ''k(T)'' at the peak (37,000 W/(m·K)) is comparable to the highest thermal conductivity ever measured (41,000 W/(m·K) for an [[isotopically pure diamond]] sample at 104 K). Even at room temperature, the thermal conductivity is quite high (6600 W/(m·K)), exceeding the reported room-temperature thermal conductivity of isotopically pure diamond by almost a factor of 2.
In graphite, the interlayer interactions quench the thermal conductivity by nearly 1 order of magnitude {{Citation needed|date=November 2009}}. It is likely that the same process occurs in nanotube bundles {{Citation needed|date=November 2009}}. Thus it is significant that the coupling between tubes in bundles is weaker than expected {{Citation needed|date=November 2009}}. It may be that this weak coupling, which is problematic for mechanical applications of nanotubes, is an advantage for thermal applications.
====Phonon density of states for nanotubes==== The phonon density of states is to calculated through band structure of isolated nanotubes, which is studied in Saito ''et al.''<ref name=Saito08> {{cite journal|title=Raman intensity of single-wall carbon nanotubes |journal=Phys. Rev. B |year=2008 |first=R. |last=Saito |author2=T. Takeya |author3=T. Kimura |author4=G. Dresselhaus |author5=M. S. Dresselhaus |volume=57 |pages=4145–53 |doi = 10.1103/PhysRevB.57.4145|bibcode = 1998PhRvB..57.4145S|issue=7 }}</ref><ref name=Saito98>{{cite book|author1=R Saito|author2=G Dresselhaus|author3=M S Dresselhaus|title=Physical Properties of Carbon Nanotubes|date=22 July 1998|publisher=World Scientific|isbn=978-1-78326-241-0|pages=229–}}</ref> and Sanchez-Portal ''et al.''<ref name=Sanchez> {{cite journal |title=Ab initio structural, elastic, and vibrational properties of carbon nanotubes |journal=Phys. Rev. B |year=1999|first=D. |last=Sanchez-Portal |author2=E. Artacho |author3=J. M. Solar |author4=A. Rubio |author5=P. Ordejon |volume=59 |issue=19 |pages=12678–88 |doi= 10.1103/PhysRevB.59.12678|arxiv = cond-mat/9811363 |bibcode = 1999PhRvB..5912678S }}</ref> When a graphene sheet is ‘‘rolled’’ into a nanotube, the 2-D band structure folds into a large number of 1-D subbands. In a (10,10) tube, for instance, the six phonon bands (three acoustic and three optical) of the graphene sheet become 66 separate 1-D subbands. A direct result of this folding is that the nanotube density of states has a number of sharp peaks due to 1-D [[Van Hove singularity|van Hove singularities]], which are absent in graphene and graphite. Despite the presence of these singularities, the overall density of states is similar at high energies, so that the high temperature specific heat should be roughly equal as well. This is to be expected: the high-energy phonons are more reflective of carbon–carbon bonding than the geometry of the graphene sheet.
==Thin films== [[Thin films]] are prevalent in the micro and nanoelectronics industry for the fabrication of sensors, actuators and transistors; thus, thermal transport properties affect the performance and reliability of many structures such as transistors, solid-state lasers, sensors, and actuators. Although these devices are traditionally made from bulk crystalline material (silicon), they often contain thin films of oxides, polysilicon, metal, as well as superlattices such as thin-film stacks of GaAs/AlGaAs for lasers.
===Single-crystal thin films=== Silicon-on-insulator (SOI) films with silicon thicknesses of 0.05 µm to 10 µm above a buried silicon dioxide layer are increasingly popular for semiconductor devices due to the increased dielectric isolation associated with SOI/<ref name=Asheghi>{{cite journal|title=Phonon-boundary scattering in thin silicon layers|journal=Applied Physics Letters|year=1997|first=M.|last=Asheghi|author2=Y. K. Leung |author3=S. S. Wong |author4=K. E. Goodson |volume=71|issue=13|pages=1798–800|doi= 10.1063/1.119402|bibcode = 1997ApPhL..71.1798A }}</ref> SOI wafers contain a thin-layer of silicon on an oxide layer and a thin-film of single-crystal silicon, which reduces the effective thermal conductivity of the material by up to 50% as compared to bulk silicon, due to phonon-interface scattering and defects and dislocations in the crystalline structure. Previous studies by Asheghi ''et al.'', show a similar trend.<ref name=Asheghi /> Other studies of thin-films show similar thermal effects {{Citation needed|date=November 2009}}.
===Superlattices=== Thermal properties associated with superlattices are critical in the development of semiconductor lasers. Heat conduction of superlattices is less understood than homogeneous thin films. It is theorized that superlattices have a lower thermal conductivity due to impurities from lattice mismatches and at the heterojunctions. Phonon-interface scattering at heterojunctions needs to be considered in this case; fully elastic scattering underestimates the heat conduction, while fully inelastic scattering overestimates the heat conduction.<ref name=GChen>{{cite journal|title=Conductivity and Heat Transfer in Superlattices|journal=Applied Physics Letters|year=1997|first=G.|last=Chen|author2=M. Neagu |volume=71|pages=2761–3|doi=10.1063/1.120126|bibcode = 1997ApPhL..71.2761C|issue=19 }}</ref><ref name=Lee>{{cite journal|title=Thermal Conductivity of Si-Ge Superlatices|journal=Applied Physics Letters|year=1997|first=S.|last=Lee|author2=D. Cahill |author3=R. Venkatasubramanian |volume=71|issue=22|pages=2957–9|doi= 10.1063/1.118755|bibcode = 1997ApPhL..70.2957L }}</ref> For example, a Si/Ge thin-film superlattice has a greater decrease in thermal conductivity than an AlAs/GaAs film stack <ref name=Yao>{{cite journal|title=Thermal Peroperties of AlAs/GaAs Superlattices|journal=Applied Physics Letters|year=1987|first=T.|last=Yao|volume=51|issue=22|pages=1798–800|doi= 10.1063/1.98526|bibcode = 1987ApPhL..51.1798Y }}</ref> due to increased lattice mismatch. A simple estimate of heat conduction of superlattices is:
:<math> k_n = \left( \frac{C_1 v_1 C_2 v_2}{C_1 v_1 + C_2 v_2} \right) \left( \frac{d_1 + d_2}{2} \right) </math>
where ''C<sub>1</sub>'' and ''C<sub>2</sub>'' are the corresponding heat capacity of film1 and film2 respectively, ''v<sub>1</sub>'' and ''v<sub>2</sub>'' are the acoustic propagation velocities in film1 and film2, and ''d1'' and ''d2'' are the thicknesses of film1 and film2. This model neglects scattering within the layers and assumes fully diffuse, inelastic scattering.<ref name= Goodson>{{cite journal|title=, Heat Conduction in Novel Electronic Films|journal=Annu. Rev. Mater. Sci.|year=1999|first=K. E.|last=Goodson|author2=S. Ju |volume=29|pages=261–93|doi=10.1146/annurev.matsci.29.1.261|bibcode = 1999AnRMS..29..261G }}</ref>
===Polycrystalline films=== Polycrystalline films are common in semiconductor devices, as the gate electrode of a [[field-effect transistor]] is often made of polycrystalline [[silicon]]. If the polysilicon grain sizes are small, internal scattering from grain boundaries can overwhelm the effects of film-boundary scattering. Also, grain boundaries contain more impurities, which result in impurity scattering. Likewise, disordered or amorphous films will experience a severe reduction of thermal conductivity, since the small grain size results in numerous grain-boundary scattering effects.<ref name=Zink>{{cite journal|title=Thermal Conductivity and Specific Heat of Thin-Film Amorphous Silicon|journal=Phys. Rev. Lett.|year=2006|first=B. L.|last=Zink|author2=R. Petri |author3=F. Hellman |volume=96|issue=5|pages=055902–6|doi= 10.1103/PhysRevLett.96.055902|pmid=16486955|bibcode=2006PhRvL..96e5902Z}}</ref> Different deposition methods of amorphous films will result in differences in impurities and grain sizes.<ref name =Goodson />
The simplest approach to modeling phonon scattering at grain boundaries is to increase the scattering rate by introducing this equation:
:<math>\tau_G^{-1}=B\frac{v}{d_G}</math>
where B is a dimensionless parameter that correlates with the phonon reflection coefficient at the grain boundaries, ''d<sub>G</sub>'' is the characteristic grain size, and ''v'' is the phonon velocity through the material. A more formal approach to estimating the scattering rate is:
:<math> {\tau_G}^{-1} = \frac{2 \nu}{\pi d_G} \left[ 1 - \exp\left(-\frac{\pi^2}{4}\nu_G \right) \right] </math>
where ''v<sub>G</sub>'' is the dimensionless grain-boundary scattering strength, defined as
:<math> \nu_G = \sum_{j} \sigma_j \nu_j </math>
Here <math>\sigma_j</math> is the cross-section of a grain-boundary area, and ''ν<sub>j</sub>'' is the density of the grain boundary area.<ref name=Goodson />
===Measuring thermal conductivity of thin films=== There are two approaches to experimentally determine the thermal conductivity of thin films. The goal of experimental metrology of thermal conductivity of thin films is to attain an accurate thermal measurement without disturbing the properties of the thin-film.
'''Electrical heating''' is used for thin films which have a lower thermal conductivity than the substrate; it is fairly accurate in measuring out-of-plane conductivity. Often, a resistive heater and thermistor is fabricated on the sample film using a highly conductive metal, such as [[aluminium]]. The most straightforward approach would be to apply a steady-state current and measure the change in temperature of adjacent thermistors. A more versatile approach uses an AC signal applied to the electrodes. The third harmonic of the AC signal reveals heating and temperature fluctuations of the material.<ref name=Goodson />
'''Laser heating''' is a non-contact metrology method, which uses picosecond and nanosecond laser pulses to deliver thermal energy to the substrate. Laser heating uses a pump-probe mechanism; the pump beam introduces energy to the thin-film, as the probe beam picks up the characteristics of how the energy propagates through the film. Laser heating is advantageous because the energy delivered to the film can be precisely controlled; furthermore, the short heating duration decouples the thermal conductivity of the thin film from the substrate {{Citation needed|date=November 2009}}.

revision.text:
{{Infobox university |name = University of Montenegro
Faculty of Biotechnology |native_name = Biotehnički fakultet
Univerziteta Crne Gore |image_name = |image_size = 200px |image_alt = |caption = |latin_name = |motto = |mottoeng = |established = 1961 |closed = |type = [[Public university|Public]] |affiliation = |endowment = |officer_in_charge = |chairman = |chancellor = |president = |vice-president = |superintendent = |provost = |vice_chancellor = |rector = |principal = |dean = [[Natalija Perović]] |director = |head_label = |head = |faculty = |staff = |students = |undergrad = |postgrad = |doctoral = |other = |city = [[Podgorica]] |country = [[Montenegro]] |coor = {{Coord|42.44372|19.243915|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |campus = [[urban area|Urban]] |former_names = |free_label = |free = |sports = |colors = |colours = |nickname = |mascot = |athletics = |affiliations = [[University of Montenegro]] |website = {{URL|http://www.btf.ac.me}} |logo = |footnotes = }} The '''University of Montenegro Biotechnical Faculty''' ([[Montenegrin language|Montenegrin]]: '''Biotehnički fakultet Univerziteta Crne Gore''' ''Биотехнички факултет Универзитета Црне Горе'') is one of the educational institutions of the [[University of Montenegro]]. The building is located in [[Podgorica]], at the University campus. == History == Scientific research in agriculture in [[Montenegro]] was established in 1937, when the Ministry of Agriculture of the [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]] decided to establish the experimental '''State Research Station for Southern Cultures''' in [[Bar, Montenegro|Bar]]. After [[World War II]], the founding of new institutions and renewal of previously existing ones followed, such as: * ''the Institute for Agricultural Research'' in Podgorica (1945) * ''the Institute for Animal Husbandry (Livestock)'' in [[Nikšić]] * ''the Institute for Southern Cultures and Viticulture'' in Bar (1947) * ''Soil Testing Units'' in Bar (1949) * ''Veterinary Diagnostic Units'' in [[Titograd]] (1950) and * ''the Centre for Fruit Growing'' in [[Bijelo Polje]] (1952). The '''Agricultural Institute''' was established in 1961, as a result of merging the above-mentioned institutions. It functioned under that name until 1997, when it was transformed into the '''Biotechnical Institute''' by including the ''Forestry Sector'' into one unique scientific research institution. By establishing the Studies of Agriculture, in 2005, the Institute developed into a faculty, and in 2008 formally changed its name into the '''Biotechnical Faculty'''.http://www.btf.ac.me/btf/BTF_brosura.pdf == Organization == The Faculty of Biotechnology has adequately equipped classrooms and laboratories situated in the Faculty's buildings in [[Podgorica]], [[Bar, Montenegro|Bar]] and [[Bijelo Polje]], as well as experimental plots for a part of students’ professional practice and organization of Faculty production.http://www.ucg.ac.me/eng/Faculty%20of%20Biotechnology.htm === Undergraduate academic studies === The undergraduate academic studies are divided in two study groups: * ''Plant production'' ** Undergraduate applied studies of ''Continental fruit growing'' in [[Bijelo Polje]] ** Undergraduate applied studies of ''Mediterranean fruit growing'' in [[Bar, Montenegro|Bar]] * ''[[Cattle breeding]]'' === Specialist academic studies === The specialist academic studies at the Faculty have four study groups: * ''Fruit and wine growing'' * ''Cultivation of soil and vegetable growing'' * ''Plant protection'' * ''Cattle breeding'' === Master studies === The master studies of Plant production are organized on the following three groups: * ''Fruit and wine growing'' * ''Cultivation of soil and vegetable growing'' * ''Plant protection'' == References == {{reflist}} {{University of Montenegro}} [[Category:Biotechnology organizations|Montenegro]] [[Category:Education in Podgorica|Biotechnology]] [[Category:Education in Bar, Montenegro|Biotechnology]] [[Category:Education in Bijelo Polje|Biotechnology]] [[Category:University of Montenegro|Biotechnology]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1961|Montenegro]] [[Category:1961 establishments in Yugoslavia]]

revision.comment: /* Etymology, translations, and cultural references */ Corrected misuse of the verb ‘substitute’. It could also have been written ‘…term is substituted for less-common loanwords…’. We replace old with new, or substitute new for old. We do not substitute the old; that’s both wrong and ambiguous.
revision.text:
{{Infobox prepared food | name = Varenye | image = Az-Strawberry jam, making by e-citizen (moonsun1981).JPG | image_size = 220px | caption = [[Strawberry]] varenye | alternate_name = | region = [[Eastern Europe]], [[Northern Europe]] ([[Baltic region]]) | creator = | course = [[Dessert]] | served = | main_ingredient = berries or other fruits, sugar | variations = | calories = | other = }} '''Varenye''' or '''varenie''' ({{lang-ru|варенье}}, {{lang-be|варэнне/варэньне}}, {{lang-uk|варення}}) is a traditional [[Fruit preserves|whole-fruit preserve]], widespread in [[Eastern Europe]] ([[Russian cuisine|Russia]], [[Ukrainian cuisine|Ukraine]], [[Belarusian cuisine|Belarus]]), as well as the [[Baltic region]] ({{lang-lt|uogienė}}, {{lang-lv|ievārījums}}, {{lang-et|moos}}). It is made by cooking berries, other fruits, or more rarely [[nut (fruit)|nuts]], [[vegetables]], or [[flowers]], in sugar syrup.<ref name=BE_Varenye>[http://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/ЭСБЕ/Варенье Варенье], Энциклопедический словарь Брокгауза и Ефрона, СПб., 1890–1907 (''Varenye'' in [[Brockhaus and Efron Encyclopedic Dictionary]], St. Petersburg, 1890–1907)</ref><ref name=Pokhlyobkin_Dict_Varenye>В. В. Похлёбкин, ''Кулинарный словарь от А до Я'', статья ''[http://dic.academic.ru/dic.nsf/dic_culinary/383/варенье Варенье]'', изд. Центрполиграф, 2000, {{ISBN|5-227-00460-9}} ([[William Pokhlyobkin]], ''Culinary Dictionary'', Centrpoligraf publishing house, 2000)</ref><ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sponsored/rbth/5767412/Russian-cuisine-Preserve-the-summer-with-fruity-varenye.html Russian cuisine: Preserve the summer with fruity varenye] by Irakli Iosebashvili, Rossiyskaya Gazeta, 2009</ref> In some traditional recipes, other sweeteners such as [[honey]] or [[treacle]] are used instead of or in addition to sugar.<ref name=BE_Varenye /><ref name=Pokhlyobkin_Dict_Varenye />
Varenye is similar to [[jam]] except the fruits are not macerated, and no [[gelling agent]] is added. It is characterized by a thick but transparent syrup having the natural colour of the fruits.
== Preparation == The making of varenye requires a careful balance between cooking, or sometimes steeping in the hot sugar mixture for just enough time to allow the flavor to be extracted from the fruit, and sugar to penetrate the fruit, and cooking too long that fruit will break down and liquefy. Some fruits with tough skins require cooking for many hours, while others are suitable for making "five-minute varenye" ({{lang-ru|варенье-пятиминутка}}, ''varenye-pyatiminutka''). For the latter, dry sugar is spread over raw fruit in layers and left for several hours to steep into the fruit. The resulting mixture is then heated for just about five minutes.
The most popular types of varenye are made from locally available berries and fruits, such as sour cherries, strawberries, raspberries, apricots and apples. In general, virtually any kind of fruit, as well as some culinary vegetables, nuts, pine cones, and rose petals are used.
<gallery mode=packed heights=180px> File:Glaswithvarenie.JPG|[[Prunus cerasus|Sour cherry]] varenye File:Peach muraba.jpg|[[Peach]] varenye File:Blackberry muraba.jpg|[[Blackberry]] varenye File:Pine Cones Jam.jpg|[[Pine]] [[Conifer cone|cone]] varenye </gallery>
== Usage ==
Varenye is enjoyed as a dessert and condiment, in particular as a topping for pancakes ([[bliny]], [[oladyi]], [[syrniki]]), as a filling for pies ([[pirog]]i and [[pirozhki]]), dumplings ([[vareniki]]), cakes and cookies, and as a sweetener for tea. It is also used as a [[spread (food)|spread]] on bread, though due to its liquid consistency it is not well suited for that. Finally, it is eaten on its own as a sweet.
== Etymology, translations, and cultural references == [[File:Vladimir Makovsky - Making Jam.JPG|thumb|[[Vladimir Makovsky]], "Making varenye", 1876]]
''Varenye'' is an old Slavic word which is used in [[East Slavic languages]] in a more general sense to refer to any type of sweet fruit preserve. The word has common etymological roots with the words denoting cooking, boiling, brewing, or stewing ({{lang-ru|варить}}, {{lang-be|варыць}}, {{lang-uk|варити}}).
In [[literary translation]]s, especially of children's books, into Russian, the term is often used to replace less-common loanwords, such as [[jam]], [[confiture]] or [[marmalade]]. Examples are the translations of [[Alice's Adventures in Wonderland]], [[Harry Potter]], [[The Adventures of Tom Sawyer]], and the animated movies about [[Karlsson-on-the-roof]].
The same is true when translating ''from'' Russian. For instance, the making of [[raspberry]] varenie is described in [[Leo Tolstoy]]'s novel ''[[Anna Karenina]]'' (VI-2). In her classic translation, [[Constance Garnett]] refers to the activity as "jam-making".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gutenberg.org/files/1399/1399-h/1399-h.htm|title=Anna Karenina|first1=Leo|last1=Tolstoy|first2=Leo|last2=Tolstoy|work=gutenberg.org}}</ref>
In the popular [[Soviet]] children's book ''A tale about a war secret, about the boy Nipper-Pipper, and his word of honour'' by [[Arkady Gaidar]] the [[antihero]] Little Baddun betrays his friends for "a barrel of varenye and a basket of biscuits" ({{lang-ru|бочка варенья и корзина печенья}}; again, in English translation ''jam'' is used instead of varenye).<ref>Arkadi Gaidar, ''A Tale About a War secret, About the Boy nipper-pipper, and His Word of Honour''. Translated from the Russian by Walter May. Progress Publishers, Moscow, 1975</ref> This phrase became an [[Idiom|idiomatic expression]] for betrayal or [[selling out]] in Russian, similar to [[thirty pieces of silver]].
== Related specialties == [[File:Dry pear varenye Kiev-style.jpg|thumb|Dry [[pear]] varenye Kiev-style]] The more general usage of the term varenye in Russian includes a number of related local specialties.
=== Raw varenye ===
In the preparation of "raw varenye" ({{lang-ru|сырое варенье}}, ''syroye varenye'') the heating is omitted completely. The recipes usually include grating of raw berries or other fruits and mixing them with sugar.
=== Dry varenye ===
In [[Russian Empire|pre-revolutionary Russia]], "dry varenye" ({{lang-ru|сухое варенье}}, ''sukhoe varenye'') referred to a local variety of [[candied fruit]]s ([[Confit#Fruit confit|fruit confit]]) obtained by extracting fruits from varenye syrup and drying them. [[Kiev]] (today the capital of Ukraine) was particularly famous for this delicacy.<ref name=BE_Varenye /><ref name=Pokhlyobkin_Dry_Varenye>В. В. Похлёбкин, ''Большая энциклопедия кулинарного искусства'', статья ''[http://dic.academic.ru/dic.nsf/enc_pohlebkin/1351/ВАРЕНЬЕ Варенье сухое (Киевское)]'', изд. Центрполиграф, 2008, {{ISBN|978-5-9524-3563-6}} ([[William Pokhlyobkin]], ''The Great Encyclopedia of Culinary Art'', Centrpoligraf, 2008)</ref><ref name="Volokh">Anne Volokh, ''The Art of Russian Cuisine'', Macmillan, 1983, p. 458</ref>
== Similar products ==
Similar confections are also made in [[Caucasian cuisine|Transcaucasia]] and in some regions of [[Central Asian cuisine|Central]] and [[South Asian cuisine|South]] Asia, where they are called [[murabba]].
== References == {{Commons category|Varenie}} <references />
{{portal bar|Food}}
[[Category:Condiments]] [[Category:Food ingredients]] [[Category:Spreads (food)]] [[Category:Food preservation]] [[Category:Russian desserts]] [[Category:Ukrainian desserts]] [[Category:Belarusian desserts]]

In [[combustion]], the '''Williams spray equation''', also known as the '''Williams–Boltzmann equation''', describes the statistical evolution of sprays contained in another fluid, analogous to the [[Boltzmann equation]] for the molecules, named after [[Forman A. Williams]], who derived the equation in 1958.<ref>Williams, F. A. "Spray combustion and atomization." The physics of fluids 1.6 (1958): 541–545</ref><ref>Williams, F. A. (1961, January). Progress in spray-combustion analysis. In Symposium (international) on Combustion (Vol. 8, No. 1, pp. 50-69). Elsevier.</ref>
==Mathematical description<ref>Williams, FA. "Combustion theory." (1985).</ref>== The sprays are assumed to be spherical with radius <math>r</math>, even though the assumption is valid for solid particles(liquid droplets) when their shape has no consequence on the combustion. For liquid droplets to be nearly spherical, the spray has to be dilute(total volume occupied by the sprays is much less than the volume of the gas) and the [[Weber number]] <math>We = 2r\rho_g|\mathbf{v}-\mathbf{u}|^2/\sigma</math>, where <math>\rho_g</math> is the gas density, <math>\mathbf{v}</math> is the spray droplet velocity, <math>\mathbf{u}</math> is the gas velocity and <math>\sigma</math> is the surface tension of the liquid spray, should be <math>We \ll 10</math>.
The equation is described by a number density function <math>f_j(r,\mathbf{x},\mathbf{v},T,t) \, dr \, d\mathbf{x} \, d\mathbf{v}\,dT</math>, which represents the probable number of spray particles (droplets) of chemical species <math>j</math> (of <math>M</math> total species), that one can find with radii between <math>r</math> and <math>r+dr</math>, located in the spatial range between <math>\mathbf{x}</math> and <math>\mathbf{x}+d\mathbf{x}</math>, traveling with a velocity in between <math>\mathbf{v}</math> and <math>\mathbf{v}+d\mathbf{v}</math>, having the temperature in between <math>T</math> and <math>T+dT</math> at time <math>t</math>. Then the spray equation for the evolution of this density function is given by
:<math>\frac{\partial f_j}{\partial t} + \nabla_x\cdot(\mathbf{v}f_j) + \nabla_v \cdot(F_jf_j) =- \frac{\partial }{\partial r}(R_jf_j) - \frac{\partial }{\partial T}(E_jf_j) + Q_j + \Gamma_j, \quad j = 1,2,\ldots,M. </math>
where :<math>F_j = \left(\frac{d\mathbf{v}}{dt}\right)_j</math> is the force per unit mass acting on the <math>j^\text{th}</math> species spray (acceleration applied to the sprays),
:<math>R_j=\left(\frac{dr}{dt}\right)_j</math> is the rate of change of the size of the <math>j^\text{th}</math> species spray,
:<math>E_j=\left(\frac{dT}{dt}\right)_j</math> is the rate of change of the temperature of the <math>j^\text{th}</math> species spray due to heat transfer,<ref>Oguz Emre, Damien Kah, St´ephane Jay, Quang-Huy Tran, Anthony Velghe, et al.. Eulerian Moment Methods for Automotive Sprays. Atomization and Sprays, Begell House Inc., 2015, 25 (3), pp. 189–254</ref>
:<math>Q_j</math> is the rate of change of number density function of <math>j^\text{th}</math> species spray due to nucleation, liquid breakup etc.,
:<math>\Gamma_j</math> is the rate of change of number density function of <math>j^\text{th}</math> species spray due to collision with other spray particles.
==A simplified model for liquid propellant rocket== This model for the rocket motor was developed by Probert,<ref>Probert, R. P. "XV. The influence of spray particle size and distribution in the combustion of oil droplets." The London, Edinburgh, and Dublin Philosophical Magazine and Journal of Science 37.265 (1946): 94–105.</ref> [[Forman A. Williams|Williams]]<ref>Williams, F. A. "Spray combustion and atomization." The physics of fluids 1.6 (1958): 541-545</ref><ref>Williams, F. A. "Introduction to Analytical Models of High Frequency Combustion Instability,”." Eighth Symposium (International) on Combustion. Williams and Wilkins. 1962.</ref> and Tanasawa.<ref>Tanasawa, Y. "On the Combustion Rate of a Group of Fuel Particles Injected Through a Swirl Nozzle." Technology Reports of Tohoku University 18 (1954): 195–208.</ref><ref>Tanasawa, Yasusi, and Tuneo Tesima. "On the theory of combustion rate of liquid fuel spray." Bulletin of JSME 1.1 (1958): 36–41.</ref> It is reasonable to neglect <math>Q_j, \ \Gamma_j</math>, for distances not very close to the spray atomizer, where major portion of combustion occurs. Consider a one-dimensional liquid-propellent rocket motor situated at <math>x=0</math>, where fuel is sprayed. Neglecting <math>E_j</math>(density function is defined without the temperature so accordingly dimensions of <math>f_j</math> changes) and due to the fact that the mean flow is parallel to <math>x</math> axis, the steady spray equation reduces to
:<math>\frac{\partial }{\partial r}(R_jf_j) + \frac{\partial }{\partial x}(u_j f_j) + \frac{\partial }{\partial u_j}(F_jf_j) = 0</math>
where <math>u_j</math> is the velocity in <math>x</math> direction. Integrating with respect to the velocity results
:<math>\frac{\partial }{\partial r}\left(\int R_j f_j \, d u_j \right) + \frac{\partial }{\partial x} \left(\int u_j f_j \, d u_j \right) + [F_jf_j]_0^\infty =0</math>
The contribution from the last term (spray acceleration term) becomes zero (using [[Divergence theorem]]) since <math>f_j\rightarrow 0</math> when <math>u</math> is very large, which is typically the case in rocket motors. The drop size rate <math>R_j</math> is well modeled using vaporization mechanisms as
:<math>R_j = -\frac{\chi_j}{r^{k_j}}, \quad \chi_j \geq 0, \quad 0\leq k_j \leq 1</math>
where <math>\chi_j</math> is independent of <math>r</math>, but can depend on the surrounding gas. Defining the number of droplets per unit volume per unit radius and average quantities averaged over velocities,
:<math>G_j = \int f_j \, du_j, \quad \bar{R}_j = \frac{\int R_j f_j \, d u_j}{G_j}, \quad \bar{u}_j = \frac{\int u_j f_j \, d u_j}{G_j}</math>
the equation becomes
:<math>\frac{\partial }{\partial r}(\bar{R}_jG_j) + \frac{\partial }{\partial x}(\bar{u}_j G_j) =0.</math>
If further assumed that <math>\bar{u}_j</math> is independent of <math>r</math>, and with a transformed coordinate
<math>\eta_j = \left[r^{k_j+1} + (k_j+1) \int_0^x \frac{\chi_j}{\bar{u}_j} \, dx \right]^{1/(k_j+1)}</math>
If the combustion chamber has varying cross-section area <math>A(x)</math>, a known function for <math>x>0</math> and with area <math>A_o</math> at the spraying location, then the solution is given by
:<math>G_j(\eta_j) = G_{j,o}(\eta_j)\frac{A_o \bar{u}_{j,o}}{A\bar{u}_j} \left(\frac{r}{\eta_j}\right)^{k_j}</math>.
where <math>G_{j,0} = G_j(r,0), \ \bar{u}_{j,0} = \bar{u}_j(x=0)</math> are the number distribution and mean velocity at <math>x=0</math> respectively.
==See also== *[[Boltzmann equation]] *[[Spray (liquid drop)]] *[[Liquid-propellant rocket]] *[[Smoluchowski coagulation equation]]
